As $\lim _{k \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\sin ^{2}(k x)}{(k x)^{2}}=\pi \delta(x)$, we have

$$
\frac{\sin ^{2}(N k x)}{\sin ^{2}(k x)}=\frac{N^{2} \sin ^{2}(N k x) /(N k x)^{2}}{\sin ^{2}(k x) /(k x)^{2}} \stackrel{k \rightarrow \infty}{\longrightarrow} \frac{\pi N^{2} \delta(N x)}{\pi \delta(x)}=N^{2} .
$$

Hence, for $k a \gg 1$ the angular distribution of the radiation in the $x y$ plane is isotropic, i.e. the distribution is a circle as illustrated in Fig. 4.39.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_6a2dacf5647d8430e732g-560.jpg?height=355&width=347&top_left_y=998&top_left_x=489)

Fig. $4.39$

\section{7}

A complicated charge distribution rotates rigidly about a fixed axis with angular velocity $\omega_{0}$. No point in the distribution is further than a distance $d$ from the axis. The motion is non-relativistic, i.e. $\omega_{0} d \ll c$ (see Fig. 4.40.)

(a) What frequencies of electromagnetic radiation may be seen by an observer at a distance $r \gg d$ ? (b) Give an order of magnitude estimate of the relative amount of power radiated at each frequency (averaged over both time and angle of observation).

$(M I T)$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_6a2dacf5647d8430e732g-561.jpg?height=370&width=196&top_left_y=435&top_left_x=568)

Fig. $4.40$

\section{Solution:}

As can be seen from Fig. 4.40, $d$ is the distance far away from the axis of rotation of the system with $v=\omega_{0} d \ll c$, so the radiation of this system can be considered as a multipole radiation.

Let $\sum(x, y, z)$ be the observer's frame and $\sum^{\prime}\left(x^{\prime}, y^{\prime}, z^{\prime}\right)$ a frame fixed on the system. The radius vector of a point in the distribution may be expressed as

$$
\xi=x \mathbf{e}_{x}+y \mathbf{e}_{x}+z \mathbf{e}_{z}=x^{\prime} \mathbf{e}_{x}^{\prime}+y^{\prime} \mathbf{e}_{y}^{\prime}+z^{\prime} \mathbf{e}_{z}^{\prime}
$$

in the $\sum$ and $\sum^{\prime}$ frames. We take the axis of rotation as the common $z$-axis of the two frames and that at $t=0$ the $x^{\prime}$-and $x$-axes, the $y^{\prime}$ - and $y$-axes coincide. We then have the transformation equations

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
x=x^{\prime} \cos \left(\omega_{0} t\right)-y^{\prime} \sin \left(\omega_{0} t\right) \\
y=x^{\prime} \sin \left(\omega_{0} t\right)+y^{\prime} \cos \left(\omega_{0} t\right) \\
z=z^{\prime}
\end{array}\right.
$$

We can now find the electric dipole moment $P(t)$, electric quadrupole moment $D(t)$ and magnetic dipole moment $m(t)$ in the $\sum$ frame. The electric dipole moment is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{P}(t)=& \int \rho \xi d V=\int \rho\left(x \mathbf{e}_{x}+y \mathbf{e}_{y}+z \mathbf{e}_{z}\right) d V \\
=& \int \rho\left\{\left[x^{\prime} \cos \left(\omega_{0} t\right)-y^{\prime} \sin \left(\omega_{0} t\right)\right] e_{x}+\left[x^{\prime} \sin \left(\omega_{0} t\right)\right.\right.\\
&\left.\left.+y^{\prime} \cos \left(\omega_{0} t\right)\right] e_{y}+z^{\prime} e_{z}\right\} d V \\
=& {\left[P_{x^{\prime}}^{\prime} \cos \left(\omega_{0} t\right)-P_{y^{\prime}}^{\prime} \sin \left(\omega_{0} t\right)\right] e_{x}+\left[P_{x^{\prime}}^{\prime} \sin \left(\omega_{0} t\right)\right.} \\
&\left.+P_{y^{\prime}}^{\prime} \cos \left(\omega_{0} t\right)\right] \mathbf{e}_{y}+P_{z^{\prime}}^{\prime} \mathbf{e}_{z}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $P_{x^{\prime}}^{\prime}, P_{y^{\prime}}^{\prime}$ and $P_{z^{\prime}}^{\prime}$ are the $x, y$ and $z$ components of the electric dipole moment in the $\sum^{\prime}$ frame in which the charge distribution is at rest. Eq. (3) shows that $P(t)$ oscillates with the frequency $\omega_{0}$. Hence the electric dipole radiation is a monochromatic radiation of angular frequency $\omega_{0}$.

As the angular velocity $\omega_{0}$ is a constant, the rotation of the charge system produces a stable current only. Hence the magnetic dipole moment of the system, $\mathbf{m}$, is a constant vector, independent of time. Therefore no magnetic dipole radiation, which is $\propto \ddot{\mathbf{m}}$, is emitted.

For the electric quadrupole moment $D(t)$, the components are given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
D_{i j}(t) &=\int\left[3 x_{i} x_{j}-\left(x_{1}^{2}+x_{2}^{2}+x_{3}^{2}\right) \delta_{i j}\right] \rho d V . \\
(i, j&\left.=1,2,3, x_{1}=x, x_{2}=y, x_{3}=z\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

For example,

$$
\begin{aligned}
D_{12} &=D_{21}=3 \int \rho x y d V \\
&=3 \int \rho\left[x^{\prime} \cos \left(\omega_{0} t\right)-y^{\prime} \sin \left(\omega_{0} t\right)\right]\left[x^{\prime} \sin \left(\omega_{0} t\right)+y^{\prime} \cos \left(\omega_{0} t\right)\right] d V \\
&=3 \int \rho\left[\frac{1}{2}\left(x^{\prime 2}-y^{\prime 2}\right) \sin \left(2 \omega_{0} t\right)+x^{\prime} y^{\prime} \cos \left(2 \omega_{0} t\right)\right] d V .
\end{aligned}
$$

In the $\sum^{\prime}$ frame the quadrupole components are

$$
D_{12}^{\prime} \equiv D_{x^{\prime} y^{\prime}}^{\prime}=3 \int \rho x^{\prime} y^{\prime} d V,
$$



$$
\begin{aligned}
D_{11}^{\prime}-D_{22}^{\prime} &=D_{x^{\prime} x^{\prime}}^{\prime}-D_{y^{\prime} y^{\prime}}^{\prime} \\
&=\int \rho\left(2 x_{1}^{\prime 2}-x_{2}^{\prime 2}-x_{3}^{\prime 2}-2 x_{2}^{\prime 2}-x_{1}^{\prime 2}-x_{3}^{\prime 2}\right) d V \\
&=3 \int \rho\left(x_{1}^{\prime 2}-x_{2}^{2}\right) d V .
\end{aligned}
$$

Note that under the rotation the charge element $\rho d V$ does not change. Thus

$$
D_{12}=D_{21}=\frac{D_{11}^{\prime}-D_{22}^{\prime}}{2} \sin \left(2 \omega_{0} t\right)+D_{12}^{\prime} \cos \left(2 \omega_{0} t\right) \text {. }
$$

Similarly, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
D_{13}=D_{31} &=3 \int \rho x z d V=3 \int \rho\left[x^{\prime} \cos \left(\omega_{0} t\right)-y^{\prime} \sin \left(\omega_{0} t\right)\right] z^{\prime} d V \\
&=D_{13}^{\prime} \cos \left(\omega_{0} t\right)-D_{23}^{\prime} \sin \left(\omega_{0} t\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

And other components of $\mathrm{D}(t)$ can be similarly obtained. It is seen from Eq. (4) and Eq. (5) that the electric quadrupole radiation is a mixture of two monochromatic angular frequencies $\omega_{0}$ and $2 \omega_{0}$.

In short, Eqs. (3), (4) and (5) show that the frequencies of electromagnetic radiation of the system are $\omega_{0}$ (electric dipole radiation, which is dominant) and $2 \omega_{0}$ (electric quadrupole radiation).

The fields of the successive multipole radiations are reduced in magnitude by a factor $k d=\frac{\omega_{0}}{c} d$. So the electric quadrupole radiation is weaker than the electric dipole radiation by a factor $\left(\frac{\omega_{0}}{c} d\right)^{2}$. 

\section{PART 5}

\section{RELATIVITY, PARTICLE-FIELD INTERACTIONS}



![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_6a2dacf5647d8430e732g-565.jpg?height=277&width=298&top_left_y=845&top_left_x=521)



\section{THE LORENTZ TRANSFORMATION (5001-5017)}

\section{1}

The radar speed trap operates on a frequency of $10^{9} \mathrm{~Hz}$. What is the beat frequency between the transmitted signal and one received after reflection from a car moving at $30 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{sec}$ ?

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

Suppose the car is moving towards the radar with velocity $v$. Let the radar frequency be $\nu_{0}$ and the frequency of the signal as received by the car be $\nu_{1}$. The situation is the same as if the car were stationary and the radar moved toward it with velocity $v$. Hence the relativistic Doppler effect gives

$$
\nu_{1}=\nu_{0} \sqrt{\frac{1+v / c}{1-v / c}} \approx \nu_{0}\left(1+\frac{v}{c}\right) \text {, }
$$

correct to the first power of $v / c$. Now the car acts like a source of frequency $\nu_{1}$, so the frequency of the reflected signal as received by the radar (also correct to the first power of $v / c)$ is

$$
\nu_{2}=\nu_{1} \sqrt{\frac{1+v / c}{1-v / c}} \approx \nu_{1}\left(1+\frac{v}{c}\right) \approx \nu_{0}\left(1+\frac{v}{c}\right)^{2} \approx \nu_{0}\left(1+\frac{2 v}{c}\right) .
$$

Thus the beat frequency is

$$
\nu_{2}-\nu_{0}=\nu_{0} \cdot \frac{2 v}{c}=10^{9} \times \frac{2 \times 30}{3 \times 10^{8}}=200 \mathrm{~Hz} \text {. }
$$

The result is the same if we had assumed the car to be moving away from the stationary radar. For then we would have to replace $v$ by $-v$ in the above and obtain $\nu_{0}-\nu_{2} \approx \nu_{0} \frac{2 v}{c}$.

\section{2}

A plane monochromatic electromagnetic wave propagating in free space is incident normally on the plane of the surface of a medium of index of refraction $n$. Relative to stationary observer, the electric field of the incident wave is given by the real part of $E_{x}^{0} e^{i(k z-\omega t)}$, where $z$ is the coordinate along the normal to the surface. Obtain the frequency of the reflected wave in the case that the medium and its surface are moving with velocity $v$ along the positive $z$ direction, with respect to the observer.

$(S U N Y, B u f f a l o)$ 

\section{Solution:}

Let the observer's frame and a frame fixed on the moving medium be $\Sigma$ and $\Sigma^{\prime}$ respectively. $\Sigma^{\prime}$ moves with velocity $v$ relative to $\Sigma$ along the $z$ direction. Let the propagation four-vectors of the incident and reflected waves in $\Sigma$ and $\Sigma^{\prime}$ be respectively

$$
\begin{aligned}
&k_{\mathrm{i}}=\left(0,0, k, \frac{\omega}{c}\right), \quad k_{\mathrm{r}}=\left(0,0,-k_{2}, \frac{\omega_{2}}{c}\right), \\
&k_{\mathrm{i}}^{\prime}=\left(0,0, k^{\prime}, \frac{\omega^{\prime}}{c}\right), \quad k_{\mathrm{r}}^{\prime}=\left(0,0,-k_{2}^{\prime}, \frac{\omega_{2}^{\prime}}{c}\right),
\end{aligned}
$$

where $k=\frac{\omega}{c}, k_{2}=\frac{\omega_{2}}{c}, k^{\prime}=\frac{\omega^{\prime}}{c}, k_{2}^{\prime}=\frac{\omega_{2}^{\prime}}{c}$.

Lorentz transformation for a four-vector gives

$$
\begin{gathered}
\frac{\omega^{\prime}}{c}=\gamma\left(\frac{\omega}{c}-\beta k\right)=\gamma \frac{\omega}{c}(1-\beta), \\
\frac{\omega_{2}}{c}=\gamma\left[\frac{\omega_{2}^{\prime}}{c}+\beta\left(-k_{2}^{\prime}\right)\right]=\gamma \frac{\omega_{2}^{\prime}}{c}(1-\beta),
\end{gathered}
$$

with $\beta=\frac{v}{c}, \gamma=\left(1-\beta^{2}\right)^{-\frac{1}{2}}$.

In $\Sigma^{\prime}$, no change of frequency occurs on reflection, i.e., $\omega_{2}^{\prime}=\omega^{\prime}$. Hence

$$
\omega_{2}=\gamma \omega^{\prime}(1-\beta)=\gamma^{2} \omega(1-\beta)^{2}=\left(\frac{1-\beta}{1+\beta}\right) \omega,
$$

being the angular frequency of the reflected wave as observed by the observer.

\section{3}

In the inertial frame of the fixed stars, a spaceship travels along the $x$-axis, with $x(t)$ being its position at time $t$. Of course, the velocity $v$ and acceleration $a$ in this frame are $v=\frac{d x}{d t}$ and $a=\frac{d^{2} x}{d t^{2}}$. Suppose the motion to be such that the acceleration as determined by the space passengers is constant in time. What this means is the following. At any instant we transform to an inertial frame in which the spaceship is momentarily at rest. Let $g$ be the acceleration of the spaceship in that frame at that instant. Now suppose that $g$, so defined instant by instant, is a constant.

You are given the constant $g$. In the fixed star frame the spaceship starts with initial velocity $v=0$ when $x=0$. What is the distance $x$ traveled when it has achieved a velocity $v$ ? 

\section{Allow for relativistic kinematics, so that $v$ is not necessarily small compared with the speed of light $c$.}

(CUSPEA)

\section{Solution:}

Consider two inertial frames $\Sigma$ and $\Sigma^{\prime}$ with $\Sigma^{\prime}$ moving with a constant velocity $v$ along the $x$ direction relative to $\Sigma$. Let the velocity and acceleration of an object moving in the $x$ direction be $u, a=\frac{d u}{d t}$, and $u^{\prime}, a^{\prime}=\frac{d u^{\prime}}{d t^{\prime}}$ in the two frames respectively. Lorentz transformation gives

$$
x=\gamma\left(x^{\prime}+\beta c t^{\prime}\right), \quad c t=\gamma\left(c t^{\prime}+\beta x^{\prime}\right),
$$

where $\beta=\frac{v}{c}, \gamma=\left(1-\beta^{2}\right)^{-\frac{1}{2}}$. Then the velocity of the object is transformed according to

$$
u=\frac{u^{\prime}+v}{1+\frac{v u^{\prime}}{c^{2}}} .
$$

Differentiating the above, we have

$$
\begin{gathered}
d t=\gamma\left(d t^{\prime}+\frac{v}{c^{2}} d x^{\prime}\right)=\gamma d t^{\prime}\left(1+\frac{v}{c^{2}} u^{\prime}\right), \\
d u=\frac{d u^{\prime}}{\gamma^{2}\left(1+\frac{v u^{\prime}}{c^{2}}\right)^{2}},
\end{gathered}
$$

whose ratio gives the transformation of acceleration:

$$
a=\frac{a^{\prime}}{\gamma^{3}\left(1+\frac{v u^{\prime}}{c^{2}}\right)^{3}} \text {. }
$$

Now assume that $\Sigma$ is the inertial frame attached to the fixed stars and $\Sigma^{\prime}$ is the inertial frame in which the spaceship is momentarily at rest. Then in $\Sigma^{\prime}$

$$
u^{\prime}=0, \quad a^{\prime}=g,
$$

and Eqs. (1) and (2) give

$$
u=v, \quad a=\frac{g}{\gamma^{3}}
$$

with $\gamma=\left(1-\frac{u^{2}}{c^{2}}\right)^{-\frac{1}{2}}$. As the velocity of the spaceship is increased from 0 to $v$ in $\Sigma$, the distance traveled is

$$
x=\int u d t=\int_{0}^{v} \frac{u d u}{a}=\frac{1}{g} \int_{0}^{v} \frac{u d u}{\left(1-\frac{u^{2}}{c^{2}}\right)^{3 / 2}}=\frac{c^{2}}{g}\left\{\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\frac{v^{2}}{c^{2}}}}-1\right\} .
$$



\section{4}

As observed in an inertial frame $S$, two spaceships are traveling in opposite directions along straight, parallel trajectories separated by a distance $d$ as shown in Fig. 5.1. The speed of each ship is $c / 2$, where $c$ is the speed of light.

(a) At the instant (as viewed from $S$ ) when the ships are at the points of closest approach (indicated by the dotted line in Fig. 5.1) ship (1) ejects a small package which has speed $3 c / 4$ (also as viewed from $S$ ). From the point of view of an observer in ship (1), at what angle must the package be aimed in order to be received by ship (2)? Assume the observer in ship (1) has a coordinate system whose axes are parallel to those of $S$ and, as shown in Fig. 5.1, the direction of motion is parallel to the $y$ axis.

(1)?

(b) What is the speed of the package as seen by the observer in ship

$(C U S P E A)$

\section{Solution:}

(a) In the inertial frame $S$, the $y$-component of the velocity of the package should be $c / 2$ in order that the package will have the same $y$ coordinate as ship $(2)$ as the package passes through the distance $\Delta x=d$. The velocity of the package in $S$ can be expressed in the form

$$
\mathbf{u}=u_{x} \mathbf{e}_{x}+u_{y} \mathbf{e}_{y}
$$

with $u_{y}=c / 2$. As $u=|\mathbf{u}|=\frac{3}{4} c$,

$$
u_{x}=\sqrt{u^{2}-u_{y}^{2}}=\frac{\sqrt{5}}{4} c .
$$

Let $S^{\prime}$ be the inertial frame fixed on ship (1). In $S^{\prime}$ the velocity of the package is

$$
\mathbf{u}^{\prime}=u_{x}^{\prime} \mathbf{e}_{x}^{\prime}+u_{y}^{\prime} \mathbf{e}_{y}^{\prime} \text {. }
$$

$S^{\prime}$ moves with speed $c / 2$ relative to $S$ along the $-y$ direction, i.e. the velocity of $S^{\prime}$ relative to $S$ is $\mathbf{v}=-c e_{y} / 2$. Velocity transformation then gives

$$
\begin{gathered}
u_{y}^{\prime}=\frac{u_{y}-v}{1-\frac{v u_{y}}{c^{2}}}=\frac{\frac{c}{2}+\frac{c}{2}}{1+\frac{1}{4}}=\frac{4}{5} c, \\
u_{x}^{\prime}=\frac{u_{x} \sqrt{1-\frac{v^{2}}{c^{2}}}}{1-\frac{v u_{y}}{c^{2}}}=\frac{\frac{\sqrt{5}}{4} c \sqrt{1-\frac{1}{4}}}{1+\frac{1}{4}}=\sqrt{\frac{3}{20}} c .
\end{gathered}
$$



![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_6a2dacf5647d8430e732g-570.jpg?height=296&width=358&top_left_y=197&top_left_x=278)

Fig. $5.1$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_6a2dacf5647d8430e732g-570.jpg?height=237&width=286&top_left_y=265&top_left_x=769)

Fig. 5.2

Let $\alpha^{\prime}$ be the angle between the velocity $\mathbf{u}^{\prime}$ of the package in $S^{\prime}$ and the $x^{\prime}$ axis as shown in Fig. 5.2. Then

$$
\tan \alpha^{\prime}=\frac{u_{y}^{\prime}}{u_{x}^{\prime}}=\frac{8}{\sqrt{15}}, \quad \text { or } \quad \alpha^{\prime}=\arctan \left(\frac{8}{\sqrt{15}}\right) \text {. }
$$

(b) In $S^{\prime}$ the speed of the package is

$$
u^{\prime}=\left|u^{\prime}\right|=\sqrt{u_{x}^{\prime 2}+u_{y}^{\prime 2}}=\frac{\sqrt{79}}{10} c .
$$

\section{5}

(a) Write down the equations of conservation of momentum and energy for the Compton effect (a photon striking a stationary electron).

(b) Find the scattered photon's energy for the case of $180^{\circ}$ back scattering. (Assume the recoiling electron proceeds with approximately the speed of light.)

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

(a) Conservation of momentum is expressed by the equations

$$
\begin{gathered}
\frac{h \nu}{c}=\frac{h \nu^{\prime}}{c} \cos \theta+\gamma m v \cos \varphi, \\
\frac{h \nu^{\prime}}{c} \sin \theta=\gamma m v \sin \varphi,
\end{gathered}
$$

where $\theta$ is the angle between the directions of motion of the incident and scattered photons, $\varphi$ is that between the incident photon and the recoiling electron, as shown in Fig. $5.3, m$ is the rest mass of an electron, $\beta=\frac{v}{c}, v$ being the speed of the recoil electron, and $\gamma=\left(1-\beta^{2}\right)^{-\frac{1}{2}}$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_6a2dacf5647d8430e732g-571.jpg?height=226&width=286&top_left_y=282&top_left_x=523)

Fig. $5.3$

Conservation of energy is expressed by the equation

$$
h \nu+m c^{2}=h \nu^{\prime}+\gamma m c^{2} .
$$
to

(b) For back scattering, $\theta=180^{\circ}, \varphi=0^{\circ}$. The above equations reduce

$$
\begin{gathered}
h \nu+h \nu^{\prime}=\gamma \beta m c^{2}, \\
h \nu-h \nu^{\prime}=(\gamma-1) m c^{2} .
\end{gathered}
$$

Squaring both sides of Eq. (1) we have

$$
\left(h \nu+h \nu^{\prime}\right)^{2}=\gamma^{2} \beta^{2} m^{2} c^{4}=\left(\gamma^{2}-1\right) m^{2} c^{4} .
$$

Combining Eqs. (2) and (3), we have

$$
4 h^{2} \nu \nu^{\prime}=2 m c^{2} h\left(\nu-\nu^{\prime}\right),
$$

or

$$
h \nu^{\prime}=\frac{h \nu}{\frac{2 h \nu}{m c^{2}}+1},
$$

which is the energy of the scattered photon.

$$
5006
$$

A charged particle is constrained to move with constant velocity $v$ in the $x$-direction (with $y=y_{0}, z=0$ fixed). It moves above an infinite perfectly conducting metal sheet that undulates with "wavelength" $L$ along the $x$-direction. A distant observer is located in the $z=0$ plane and detects the electromagnetic radiation emitted at angle $\theta$ (the angle between the velocity vector and a vector drawn from the charge to the observer) as shown in Fig. 5.4. What is the wavelength $\lambda$ of the radiation detected by the observer?

(Princeton)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_6a2dacf5647d8430e732g-572.jpg?height=298&width=362&top_left_y=345&top_left_x=477)

Fig. $5.4$

Solution:

The induced charges in the metal sheet will move on the surface of the sheet along the general direction of motion of the charged particle. The acceleration of the induced charges moving on the undulating surface will lead to emission of bremsstrahlung (braking radiation). The radiation detected by a distant observer located along the $\theta$ direction is that resulting from the constructive interference in that direction. Hence, the wavelength of the radiation satisfies the condition

$$
\frac{L}{v}-\frac{L \cos \theta}{c}=m \frac{\lambda}{c},
$$

where $m$ is an integer, or

$$
\lambda_{m}=\frac{L}{m}\left(\frac{c}{v}-\cos \theta\right)
$$

For $m=1, \lambda_{1}=L\left(\frac{c}{v}-\cos \theta\right)$.

We can also approach the problem by regarding the effect of the metal sheet as that of an image charge, which together with the real charge forms an oscillating dipole of velocity $v=v e_{x}$ and frequency of vibration $f_{0}=\frac{v}{L}$. From the formula of Doppler shift the frequency detected by the observer is

$$
f(\theta)=\frac{1+\beta \cos \theta}{\sqrt{1-\beta^{2}}} f_{0} \approx\left(1+\frac{v}{c} \cos \theta\right) f,
$$

and the corresponding wavelength is

$$
\lambda(\theta)=\frac{c}{f}=\frac{c L}{v}\left(1-\frac{v}{c} \cos \theta\right) .
$$

This result is the same as the foregoing $\lambda_{1}$. 

\section{7}

Two large parallel plates (non-conducting), separated by a distance $d$ and oriented as shown in Fig. $5.5$, move together along $x$-axis with velocity $v$, not necessarily small compared with $c$. The upper and lower plates have uniform surface charge densities $+\sigma$ and $-\sigma$ respectively in the rest frame of the plates. Find the magnitude and direction of the electric and magnetic fields between the plates (neglecting edge effects).

(Columbia)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_6a2dacf5647d8430e732g-573.jpg?height=208&width=378&top_left_y=566&top_left_x=477)

Fig. $5.5$

\section{Solution:}

Let the electromagnetic fields be $\mathbf{E}^{\prime}, \mathrm{B}^{\prime}$ in frame $S^{\prime}\left(0 x^{\prime} y^{\prime} z^{\prime}\right)$ where the plates are at rest; and be $\mathbf{E}, \mathbf{B}$ in the laboratory frame $S(0 x y z)$. The field vectors transform according to

$$
\begin{gathered}
E_{x}=E_{x}^{\prime}, \quad B_{x}=B_{x}^{\prime}, \\
E_{y}=\gamma\left(E_{y}^{\prime}+\beta c B_{z}^{\prime}\right), \quad B_{y}=\gamma\left(B_{y}^{\prime}-\frac{\beta}{c} E_{z}^{\prime}\right), \\
E_{z}=\gamma\left(E_{z}^{\prime}-\beta c B_{y}^{\prime}\right), \quad B_{z}=\gamma\left(B_{z}^{\prime}+\frac{\beta}{c} E_{y}^{\prime}\right),
\end{gathered}
$$

where $\beta=\frac{v}{c}, \gamma=\left(1-\beta^{2}\right)^{-\frac{1}{2}}$.

In the rest frame $S^{\prime}$,

$$
\begin{gathered}
B_{x}^{\prime}=B_{y}^{\prime}=B_{z}^{\prime}=0, \\
E_{x}^{\prime}=E_{y}^{\prime}=0, \quad E_{z}^{\prime}=-\frac{\sigma}{\varepsilon_{0}},
\end{gathered}
$$

so that

$$
\begin{gathered}
E_{x}=0, \quad B_{x}=0, \\
E_{y}=0, \quad B_{y}=\frac{\gamma \beta}{\varepsilon_{0} c} \sigma, \\
E_{z}=-\frac{\gamma \sigma}{\varepsilon_{0}}, \quad B_{z}=0 .
\end{gathered}
$$

Hence in the laboratory frame, the electric intensity is in the $-z$ direction and has magnitude $\frac{\gamma \sigma}{\varepsilon_{0}}$, while the magnetic induction is in the $+y$ direction and has magnitude $\frac{\gamma v}{\varepsilon_{0} c^{2}} \sigma$, where $\gamma=\left(1-\frac{v^{2}}{c^{2}}\right)^{-\frac{1}{2}}$.

\section{8}

Show that $E^{2}-B^{2}$ and $\mathbf{E} \cdot \mathbf{B}$ are invariant under a Lorentz transformation.

$(U C$, Berkeley)

\section{Solution:}

Decompose the electromagnetic field into longitudinal and transverse components with respect to the direction of the relative velocity between two inertial frames $\boldsymbol{\Sigma}$ and $\boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{\prime}$. In $\boldsymbol{\Sigma}$, we have

$$
\mathbf{\Sigma}=\mathbf{E}_{\perp}+\mathbf{E}_{\|}, \quad \mathbf{B}=\mathbf{B}_{\perp}+\mathbf{B}_{\|}
$$

In $\Sigma^{\prime}$, which moves with velocity $v$ relative to $\Sigma$, we have (in Gaussian units)

$$
\begin{gathered}
\mathbf{\Sigma}_{\|}^{\prime}=\mathbf{\Sigma}_{\|}, \quad \mathbf{B}_{\|}^{\prime}=\mathbf{B}_{\|}, \\
\mathbf{E}_{\perp}^{\prime}=\gamma\left(\mathbf{E}_{\perp}+\frac{\mathbf{v}}{c} \times \mathbf{B}_{\perp}\right), \\
\mathbf{B}_{\perp}^{\prime}=\gamma\left(\mathbf{B}_{\perp}-\frac{\mathbf{v}}{c} \times \mathbf{E}_{\perp}\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

where

$$
\gamma=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-v^{2} / c^{2}}}
$$

\section{Thus}

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{E}^{\prime} \cdot \mathbf{B}^{\prime} &=\mathbf{E}_{\|}^{\prime} \cdot \mathbf{B}_{\|}^{\prime}+\mathbf{E}_{\perp}^{\prime} \cdot \mathbf{B}_{\perp}^{\prime} \\
&=\mathbf{E}_{\|} \cdot \mathbf{B}_{\|}+\gamma^{2}\left[\mathbf{E}_{\perp} \cdot \mathbf{B}_{\perp}-\frac{\left(\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{B}_{\perp}\right) \cdot\left(\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{E}_{\perp}\right)}{c^{2}}\right] .
\end{aligned}
$$

As $\mathbf{v}$ is perpendicular to both $\mathbf{B}_{\perp}$ and $\mathbf{E}_{\perp}$, we have

$$
\left(\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{B}_{\perp}\right) \cdot\left(\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{E}_{\perp}\right)=v^{2} \mathbf{E} \perp \cdot B_{\perp},
$$

so that

$$
\mathbf{E}^{\prime} \cdot \mathbf{B}^{\prime}=\mathbf{E}_{\|} \cdot \mathbf{B}_{\|}+\gamma^{2}\left(1-\frac{v^{2}}{c^{2}}\right) \mathbf{E}_{\perp} \cdot \mathbf{B}_{\perp}=\mathbf{E}_{\|} \cdot \mathbf{B}_{\|}+\mathbf{E}_{\perp} \cdot \mathbf{B}_{\perp}=\mathbf{E} \cdot \mathbf{B}
$$

From the expression for $\mathbf{E}_{\perp}^{\prime}$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{E}_{\perp}^{\prime 2} &=\gamma^{2}\left[\mathbf{E}_{\perp}^{2}+\frac{1}{c^{2}}\left(\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{B}_{\perp}\right)^{2}+2 \mathbf{E}_{\perp} \cdot\left(\frac{\mathbf{v}}{c} \times \mathbf{B}_{\perp}\right)\right] \\
&=\gamma^{2}\left(\mathbf{E}_{\perp}^{2}+\frac{v^{2}}{c^{2}} \mathbf{B}_{\perp}^{2}+\frac{2 \mathbf{E}_{\perp} \cdot\left(\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{B}_{\perp}\right)}{c}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\mathbf{B}_{\perp}^{\prime 2}=\gamma^{2}\left(\mathbf{B}_{\perp}^{2}+\frac{v^{2}}{c^{2}} \mathbf{E}_{\perp}^{2}-\frac{2 \mathbf{B}_{\perp} \cdot\left(\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{E}_{\perp}\right)}{c}\right) .
$$

Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{E}^{\prime 2}-\mathbf{B}^{\prime 2}=\left(\mathbf{E}_{\|}^{\prime}+\mathbf{E}_{\perp}^{\prime}\right)^{2}-\left(\mathbf{B}_{\|}^{\prime}+\mathbf{B}_{\perp}^{\prime}\right)^{2} \\
=& \mathbf{E}_{\|}^{\prime 2}-\mathbf{B}_{\|}^{\prime 2}+\mathbf{E}_{\perp}^{\prime 2}-\mathbf{B}_{\perp}^{\prime 2} \\
=&\left(\mathbf{E}_{\|}^{2}-\mathbf{B}_{\|}^{2}\right)+\gamma^{2}\left(\mathbf{E}_{\perp}^{2}+\frac{v^{2}}{c^{2}} \mathbf{B}_{\perp}^{2}-\mathbf{B}_{\perp}^{2}-\frac{v^{2}}{c^{2}} \mathbf{E}_{\perp}^{2}\right) \\
&+\frac{2 \gamma^{2}}{c}\left[\mathbf{E}_{\perp} \cdot \mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{B}_{\perp}+\mathbf{B}_{\perp} \cdot \mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{E}_{\perp}\right] \\
=&\left(\mathbf{E}_{\|}^{2}-\mathbf{B}_{\|}^{2}\right)+\left(\mathbf{E}_{\perp}^{2}-\mathbf{B}_{\perp}^{2}\right) \\
=& \mathbf{E}^{2}-\mathbf{B}^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

since $\mathbf{E}_{\perp} \cdot \mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{B}_{\perp}=\mathbf{E}_{\perp} \times \mathbf{v} \cdot \mathbf{B}_{\perp}=-\mathbf{B}_{\perp} \cdot \mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{E}_{\perp}$ for a box product.

Therefore $\mathbf{E}^{2}-\mathbf{B}^{2}$ and $\mathbf{E} \cdot \mathbf{B}$ are invariant under a Lorentz transformation. Note that in SI units it is $\mathbf{E}^{2}-c^{2} \mathbf{B}^{2}$ that is Lorentz invariant.

\section{9}

\section{(a) A classical electromagnetic wave satisfies the relations}

$$
\mathbf{E} \cdot \mathbf{B}=0, \quad \mathbf{E}^{2}=c^{2} \mathbf{B}^{2}
$$

between the electric and magnetic fields. Show that these relations, if satisfied in any one Lorentz frame, are valid in all frames. (b) If $K$ is a unit three-vector in the direction of propagation of the wave, then according to classical electromagnetism, $\mathbf{K} \cdot \mathbf{E}=\mathbf{K} \cdot \mathbf{B}=\mathbf{0}$. Show that this statement is also invariant under Lorentz transformation by showing its equivalence to the manifestly Lorentz invariant statement $n^{\mu} F_{\mu \nu}=0$, where $n^{\mu}$ is a four-vector oriented in the direction of propagation of the wave and $F_{\mu \nu}$ is the field strength tensor.

Parts (a) and (b) together show that what looks like a light wave in one frame looks like one in any frame. form

(c) Consider an electromagnetic wave which in some frame has the

$$
E_{x}=c B_{y}=f(c t-z), \text {, }
$$

where $\lim _{z \rightarrow \pm \infty} f(z) \rightarrow 0$. What would be the values of the fields in a different coordinate system moving with velocity $v$ in the $z$ direction relative to the frame in which the fields are as given above? Give an expression for the energy and momentum densities of the wave in the original frame and in the frame moving with velocity $v$, show that the total energy-momentum of the wave transforms as a four-vector under the transformation between the two frames. (Assume the extent of the wave in the $x-y$ plane is large but finite, so that its total energy and momentum are finite.)

\section{Solution:}

(a) It has been shown in Problem 5008 that $\mathbf{E} \cdot \mathbf{B}, \mathbf{E}^{2}-c^{2} \mathbf{B}^{2}$ are Lorentz invariant. Hence in another Lorentz frame $\Sigma^{\prime}$ we have

$$
\mathbf{E}^{\prime} \cdot \mathbf{B}^{\prime}=\mathbf{E} \cdot \mathbf{B}=0, \quad \mathbf{E}^{\prime 2}-c^{2} \mathbf{B}^{\prime 2}=\mathbf{E}^{2}-c^{2} \mathbf{B}^{2}=0
$$

i.e.

$$
\mathbf{E}^{\prime} \cdot \mathbf{B}^{\prime}=0, \quad \mathbf{E}^{\prime 2}=c^{2} \mathbf{B}^{\prime 2} .
$$

(b) The electromagnetic field tensor can be represented by the matrix

$$
F_{\mu \nu}=\left(\begin{array}{cccc}
0 & -c B_{3} & c B_{2} & -E_{1} \\
c B_{3} & 0 & -c B_{1} & -E_{2} \\
-c B_{2} & c B_{1} & 0 & -E_{3} \\
E_{1} & E_{2} & E_{3} & 0
\end{array}\right) .
$$

Using the electromagnetic wave propagation four-vector $K^{\mu}=\left(K_{1}, K_{2}\right.$, $\left.K_{3}, \frac{w}{c}\right)$ where $K=\frac{w}{c}$, we can express $n^{\mu} \equiv \frac{1}{K} K^{\mu} \cdot n^{\mu} F_{\mu \nu}=0$ which is then equivalent to $K^{\mu} F_{\mu \nu}=0$. For $\nu=1$, we have

$$
+K_{2} c B_{3}-K_{3} c B_{2}+\frac{\omega}{c} E_{1}=0,
$$

or

$$
E_{1}=\frac{c}{K}(\mathbf{B} \times \mathbf{K})_{1} .
$$

Similar expressions are obtained for $E_{2}$ and $E_{3}$. Hence

$$
\mathbf{E}=\frac{\boldsymbol{c}}{K}(\mathbf{B} \times \mathbf{K}) .
$$

For $\nu=4$, we have

$$
-K_{1} E_{1}-K_{2} E_{2}-K_{3} E_{3}=0,
$$

or

$$
\boldsymbol{K} \cdot \boldsymbol{\Sigma}=\mathbf{0} \text {. }
$$

Since $n^{\mu} F_{\mu \nu}=0$ is Lorentz covariant, it has the same form in all inertial frames. This means that Eqs. (1) and (2) are valid in all inertial frames. Now Eq. (1) gives

$$
\mathbf{E}^{2}=\frac{c^{2}}{K^{2}}(\mathbf{B} \times \mathbf{K}) \cdot(\mathbf{B} \times \mathbf{K})=c^{2} \mathbf{B}^{2}-c^{2}(\mathbf{B} \cdot \mathbf{K})^{2}
$$

From (a) we see that if $\mathbf{E}^{2}=c^{2} \mathbf{B}^{2}$ is valid in an inertial frame it is valid in all inertial frames. Since this relation is given for one inertial frame, Eq. (3) means that the relation $\mathbf{K} \cdot \mathbf{B}=0$ is satisfied in all inertial frames.

(c) In frame $\Sigma$ one has

$$
\begin{gathered}
E_{x}=f(c t-z), \quad E_{y}=E_{z}=0, \\
B_{x}=0, \quad B_{y}=\frac{1}{c} f(c t-z), \quad B_{z}=0 .
\end{gathered}
$$

Suppose a frame $\Sigma^{\prime}$ moves with velocity $v$ relative to $\Sigma$ frame along the $z$-axis. Then Lorentz transformation gives

$$
\begin{gathered}
E_{z}^{\prime}=E_{z}=0, \quad E_{y}^{\prime}=\gamma\left(E_{y}+v B_{x}\right)=0, \\
E_{x}^{\prime}=\gamma\left(E_{x}-v B_{y}\right)=\gamma(1-\beta) f(c t-z), \\
B_{z}^{\prime}=B_{z}=0, \quad B_{x}^{\prime}=\gamma\left(B_{x}+\frac{\beta}{c} E_{y}\right)=0, \\
B_{y}^{\prime}=\gamma\left(B_{y}-\frac{\beta}{c} E_{x}\right)=\frac{\gamma}{c}(1-\beta) f(c t-z),
\end{gathered}
$$

where

$$
\beta=\frac{v}{c}, \quad \gamma=\left(1-\beta^{2}\right)^{-\frac{1}{2}} .
$$

The energy densities in frames $\Sigma$ and $\Sigma^{\prime}$ are respectively given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
w &=\frac{1}{2}\left(\varepsilon_{0} E^{2}+\frac{B^{2}}{\mu_{0}}\right)=\varepsilon_{0} f^{2}(c t-z), \\
w^{\prime} &=\frac{1}{2}\left(\varepsilon_{0} E^{\prime 2}+\frac{B^{\prime 2}}{\mu_{0}}\right)=\varepsilon_{0} \gamma^{2}(1-\beta)^{2} f^{2}(c t-z) .
\end{aligned}
$$

The inverse Lorentz transformation $z=\gamma\left(z^{\prime}+\beta c t^{\prime}\right), c t=\gamma\left(c t^{\prime}+\beta z^{\prime}\right)$ gives

$$
c t-z=\gamma(1-\beta)\left(c t^{\prime}-z^{\prime}\right) \text {. }
$$

Thus

$$
w^{\prime}=\varepsilon_{0} \gamma^{2}(1-\beta)^{2} f^{2}\left[\gamma(1-\beta)\left(c t^{\prime}-z^{\prime}\right)\right] .
$$

The momentum density is

$$
g=\frac{\mathbf{E} \times \mathbf{H}}{c^{2}}=\frac{\mathbf{E} \times \mathbf{B}}{c^{2} \mu_{0}}=\varepsilon_{0} \mathbf{E} \times \mathbf{B}=\varepsilon_{0} E_{x} B_{y} \mathbf{e}_{z} .
$$

Hence the momentum density as seen in $\Sigma$ and $\Sigma^{\prime}$ has components

$$
\begin{gathered}
g_{x}=g_{y}=0, \quad g_{z}=\frac{\varepsilon_{0}}{c} f^{2}(c t-z), \\
g_{x}^{\prime}=g_{y}^{\prime}=0, \quad g_{z}^{\prime}=\frac{\varepsilon_{0}}{c} \gamma^{2}(1-\beta)^{2} f^{2}\left[\gamma(1-\beta)\left(c t^{\prime}-z^{\prime}\right)\right] .
\end{gathered}
$$

The total energy and the total momentum are

$$
\begin{gathered}
W=\int_{V} w d V=\varepsilon_{0} \int_{V} f^{2}(c t-z) d V \\
G_{x}=G_{y}=0, \quad G_{z}=\frac{\varepsilon_{0}}{c} \int_{V} f^{2}(c t-z) d V=\frac{W}{c}
\end{gathered}
$$

in $\Sigma$ and

$$
\begin{aligned}
W^{\prime} &=\int_{V^{\prime}} w^{\prime} d V^{\prime} \\
&=\varepsilon_{0} \gamma^{2}(1-\beta)^{2} \int_{V^{\prime}} f^{2}\left[\gamma\left(1-\frac{v}{c}\right)\left(c t^{\prime}-z^{\prime}\right)\right] d V^{\prime},
\end{aligned}
$$



$$
\begin{aligned}
&G_{x}^{\prime}=G_{y}^{\prime}=0 \\
&G_{z}^{\prime}=\frac{\varepsilon_{0}}{c} \gamma^{2}(1-\beta)^{2} \int_{V^{\prime}} f^{2}\left[\gamma(1-\beta)\left(c t^{\prime}-z^{\prime}\right)\right] d V^{\prime}=\frac{W^{\prime}}{c}
\end{aligned}
$$

in $\Sigma^{\prime}$

As the wave has finite extension, $V$ and $V^{\prime}$ must contain the same finite number of waves in the direction of propagation, i.e. the $z$ direction. As Eq. (4) requires

$$
\begin{aligned}
&d V=\gamma(1-\beta) d V^{\prime}, \\
&W^{\prime}=\gamma(1-\beta) W .
\end{aligned}
$$

Similarly

$$
G_{z}^{\prime}=\frac{W^{\prime}}{c}=\gamma(1-\beta) G_{z}
$$

Thus the transformation equations for total energy-momentum are

$$
G_{x}^{\prime}=G_{x}, \quad G_{y}^{\prime}=G_{y}, \quad G_{z}^{\prime}=\gamma\left(G_{z}-\beta \frac{W}{c}\right), \quad \frac{W^{\prime}}{c}=\gamma\left(\frac{W}{c}-\beta G_{z}\right) .
$$

That is, $\left(\mathbf{G}, \frac{W}{c}\right)$ transforms like a four-vector.

\section{0}

An infinitely long perfectly conducting straight wire of radius $r$ carries a constant current $i$ and charge density zero as seen by a fixed observer $A$. The current is due to an electron stream of uniform density moving with high (relativistic) velocity $U$. A second observer B travels parallel to the wire with high (relativistic) velocity $v$. As seen by the observer B:

(a) What is the electromagnetic field?

(b) What is the charge density in the wire implied by this field?

(c) With what velocities do the electron and ion streams move?

(d) How do you account for the presence of a charge density seen by $B$ but not by $A$ ?

(Princeton)

\section{Solution:}

(a) Let $\Sigma$ and $\Sigma^{\prime}$ be the rest frames of the observers $A$ and $B$ respectively, the common $x$-axis being along the axis of the conducting wire, which is fixed in $\Sigma$, as shown in Fig. 5.6. In $\Sigma, \rho=0, j=\frac{i}{\pi r_{0}^{2}} \mathbf{e}_{x}$, so the electric and magnetic fields in $\Sigma$ are respectively

$$
\begin{gathered}
\mathbf{E}=0, \\
\mathbf{B}(r)= \begin{cases}\frac{\mu_{0} i r}{2 \pi r_{0}^{2}} \mathbf{e}_{\varphi}, & \left(r<r_{0}\right) \\
\frac{\mu_{0} i}{2 \pi r} \mathbf{e}_{\varphi}, & \left(r>r_{0}\right)\end{cases}
\end{gathered}
$$

where $\mathbf{e}_{x}, \mathbf{e}_{r}$, and $\mathbf{e}_{\varphi}$ form an orthogonal system. Lorentz transformation gives the electromagnetic field as seen in $\Sigma^{\prime}$ as

$$
\begin{gathered}
E_{\|}^{\prime}=E_{\|}=0, \quad B_{\|}^{\prime}=B_{\|}=0, \\
\mathbf{E}^{\prime}=\mathbf{E}_{\perp}^{\prime}=\gamma\left(\mathbf{E}_{\perp}+\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{B}_{\perp}\right)=-\gamma v B \mathbf{e}_{r}= \begin{cases}-\frac{\mu_{0} \gamma i v r}{2 \pi r_{0}^{2}} \mathbf{e}_{r}, & \left(r<r_{0}\right) \\
-\frac{\mu_{0} \gamma i v}{2 \pi r} \mathbf{e}_{r}, & \left(r>r_{0}\right)\end{cases} \\
\mathbf{B}^{\prime}=\mathbf{B}_{\perp}^{\prime}=\gamma\left(\mathbf{B}_{\perp}-\frac{\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{E}_{\perp}}{c^{2}}\right)=\gamma B \mathbf{e}_{\varphi}= \begin{cases}\frac{\mu_{0} i \gamma r}{2 \pi r_{0}^{2}} \mathbf{e}_{\varphi}, & \left(r<r_{0}\right) \\
\frac{\mu_{0} i \gamma}{2 \pi r} \mathbf{e}_{\varphi}, & \left(r>r_{0}\right)\end{cases}
\end{gathered}
$$

where $\gamma=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-v^{2} / c^{2}}}$, and the lengths $r$ and $r_{0}$ are not changed by the transformation.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_6a2dacf5647d8430e732g-580.jpg?height=197&width=380&top_left_y=1046&top_left_x=476)

Fig. $5.6$

(b) Let the charge density of the wire in $\Sigma^{\prime}$ be $\rho^{\prime}$, then the electric field produced by $\rho^{\prime}$ for $r<r_{0}$ is given by Gauss' law

$$
2 \pi r E_{r}^{\prime}=\rho^{\prime} \pi r^{2} / \varepsilon_{0}
$$

to be

$$
\mathbf{E}^{\prime}=\frac{\rho^{\prime} r}{2 \varepsilon_{0}} \mathbf{e}_{r} . \quad\left(r<r_{0}\right)
$$

Comparing this with the expression for $\mathbb{}^{\prime}$ above we have

$$
\rho^{\prime}=-\frac{v i \gamma}{\pi r_{0}^{2} c^{2}},
$$

where we have used $\mu_{0} \varepsilon_{0}=\frac{1}{c^{2}}$. (c) In $\Sigma$ the velocity of the electron stream is $\mathbf{v}_{e}=-U e_{x}$, while the ions are stationary, i.e. $v_{\mathrm{i}}=0$. Using the Lorentz transformation of velocity we have in $\boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{\prime}$

$$
\mathbf{v}_{e}^{\prime}=-\frac{v+U}{1+\frac{v U}{c^{2}}} \mathbf{e}_{x}, \quad \mathbf{v}_{i}^{\prime}=-v \mathbf{e}_{x} .
$$

(d) The charge density is zero in $\Sigma$. That is, the positive charges of the positive ions are neutralized by the negative charges of the electrons. Thus $\rho_{e}+\rho_{i}=0$, where $\rho_{e}$ and $\rho_{i}$ are the charge densities of the electrons and ions. As

$$
\rho_{\mathrm{e}}=\frac{j}{-U}=-\frac{i}{\pi r_{0}^{2} U}
$$

we have

$$
\rho_{\mathrm{i}}=\frac{i}{\pi r_{0}^{2} U} .
$$

However, the positive ions are at rest in $\Sigma$ and do not give rise to a current. Hence

$$
\mathbf{j}_{e}=\mathbf{j}=\frac{i}{\pi r_{0}^{2}} \mathbf{e}_{x}, \quad \mathbf{j}_{i}=0 .
$$

$\left(\frac{\mathfrak{j}}{c}, \rho\right)$ form a four-vector, so the charge densities of the electrons and ions in $\Sigma^{\prime}$ are respectively

$$
\begin{gathered}
\rho_{\mathrm{e}}^{\prime}=\gamma\left(\rho_{\mathrm{e}}-\frac{v}{c^{2}} j_{\mathrm{e}}\right)=-\frac{i \gamma}{\pi r_{0}^{2} U}-\frac{v i \gamma}{\pi r_{0}^{2} c^{2}}, \\
\rho_{\mathrm{i}}^{\prime}=\gamma \rho_{\mathrm{i}}=\frac{i \gamma}{\pi r_{0}^{2} U} .
\end{gathered}
$$

Obviously, $\rho_{\mathrm{e}}^{\prime}+\rho_{\mathrm{i}}^{\prime} \neq 0$, but the sum of $\rho_{\mathrm{e}}^{\prime}$ and $\rho_{\mathrm{i}}^{\prime}$ is just the charge density $\rho^{\prime}$ detected by B.

\section{1}

(a) Derive the repulsive force on an electron at a distance $r<a$ from the axis of a cylindrical column of electrons of uniform charge density $\rho_{0}$ and radius $a$.

(b) An observer in the laboratory sees a beam of circular cross section and density $\rho$ moving at velocity $v$. What force does he see on an electron of the beam at distance $r<a$ from the axis? (c) If $v$ is near the velocity of light, what is the force of part (b) as seen by an observer moving with the beam? Compare this force with the answer to part (b) and comment.

(d) If $n=2 \times 10^{10} \mathrm{~cm}^{-3}$ and $v=0.99 c$ ( $c=$ light velocity), what gradient of a transverse magnetic field would just hold this beam from spreading in one its dimensions?

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

(a) Use cylindrical coordinates with the $z$-axis along the axis of the cylindrical column of electrons. By Gauss' flux theorem and the symmetry we obtain the electric field at a distance $r<a$ from the axis:

$$
\mathbf{E}(r)=\frac{\rho_{0} r}{2 \varepsilon_{0}} \mathbf{e}_{r} \cdot \quad(r<a)
$$

Thus the force on an electron at that point is

$$
\mathbf{F}=-e \mathbf{E}=-\frac{e \rho_{0} r}{2 \varepsilon_{0}} \mathbf{e}_{r} .
$$

Note that this is a repulsive force as $\rho_{0}$ itself is negative.

(b) Let the rest frame of the column of electrons and the laboratory frame be $\Sigma^{\prime}$ and $\Sigma$ respectively with $\Sigma^{\prime}$ moving with velocity $v$ relative to $\Sigma$ along the $z$-axis. By transforming the current-charge density four-vector we find $\rho=\gamma \rho_{0}$, where $\gamma=\left(1-\frac{v^{2}}{c^{2}}\right)^{-\frac{1}{2}}$. In $\Sigma^{\prime}$ the electric and magnetic fields are $\mathbf{E}^{\prime}=\frac{\rho_{0} r^{\prime}}{2 \varepsilon_{0}} \mathbf{e}_{r}, \mathbf{B}^{\prime}=0$. In $\Sigma$, one has

$$
\begin{gathered}
\mathbf{E}_{\perp}=\gamma\left(\mathbf{E}_{\perp}^{\prime}-\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{B}_{\perp}^{\prime}\right)=\gamma \mathbf{E}^{\prime}, \quad \mathbf{E}_{\|}=\mathbf{E}_{\|}^{\prime}=0 \\
\mathbf{B}_{\perp}=\gamma\left(\mathbf{B}_{\perp}^{\prime}+\frac{\mathbf{v}}{c^{2}} \times \mathbf{E}_{\perp}^{\prime}\right)=\gamma \frac{\mathbf{v}}{c^{2}} \times \mathbf{E}^{\prime}, \quad \mathbf{B}_{\|}=\mathbf{B}_{\|}^{\prime}=0 .
\end{gathered}
$$

Thus the force on an electron of the beam at $r<a$ is given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{F} &=-e \mathbf{E}-e \mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{B}=-e \gamma \mathbf{E}^{\prime}-e \mathbf{v} \times\left(\gamma \frac{\mathbf{v}}{c^{2}} \times \mathbf{E}^{\prime}\right) \\
&=-e \gamma \mathbf{E}^{\prime}+e \gamma \frac{v^{2}}{c^{2}} \mathbf{E}^{\prime}
\end{aligned}
$$

as $\mathbf{v}=\boldsymbol{v} \mathbf{e}_{z}$ is perpendicular to $\mathbf{E}^{\prime}$. As there is no transverse Lorentz contraction, $r=r^{\prime}$. Hence

$$
\mathbf{F}=-\frac{e \mathbf{E}^{\prime}}{\gamma}=-\frac{e \rho \boldsymbol{\rho}}{2 \varepsilon_{0} \gamma^{2}} \mathbf{e}_{r} .
$$

(c) In $\Sigma^{\prime}$ the force on the electron is

$$
\mathbf{F}^{\prime}=-e \mathbf{E}^{\prime}=-\frac{e \rho_{0} r}{2 \varepsilon_{0}} \mathbf{e}_{r}=-\frac{e \rho r}{2 \varepsilon_{0} \gamma} \mathbf{e}_{r} .
$$

As $\gamma>1, F^{\prime}>F$. Actually, in the rest frame $\Sigma^{\prime}$ only the electric field exerts a force on the electron, while in the laboratory frame $\Sigma$, although the electric force is larger, there is also a magnetic force acting opposite in direction to the electric force. As a result the total force on the electron is smaller as seen in $\boldsymbol{\Sigma}$.

(d) In $\Sigma$ the force on the electron is

$$
\mathbf{F}=-\frac{e \rho r}{2 \varepsilon_{0} \gamma^{2}} \mathbf{e}_{r} .
$$

The additional magnetic field $B_{0}$ necessary to keep it stationary is given by

$$
-e \mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{B}_{0}+\mathbf{F}=0,
$$

i.e.,

$$
e v \times \mathbf{B}_{0}+\frac{e \rho r}{2 \varepsilon_{0} \gamma^{2}} \mathbf{e}_{r}=0 .
$$

As $v=v \mathbf{e}_{z}$, the above requires

$$
\mathbf{B}_{0}=\frac{\rho r}{2 \varepsilon_{0} \gamma^{2} v} \mathbf{e}_{\theta} .
$$

The gradient of the magnetic field is then

$$
\frac{d B_{0}}{d r}=\frac{\rho}{2 \varepsilon_{0} \gamma^{2} v}=-\frac{n e}{2 \varepsilon_{0} \gamma^{2} v} .
$$

With $n=2 \times 10^{10} \times 10^{6} \mathrm{~m}^{-3}, v=0.99 c, \varepsilon_{0}=8.84 \times 10^{-12} \mathrm{C} / \mathrm{Vm}$, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|\frac{d B_{0}}{d r}\right| &=\left|-\frac{2 \times 10^{16} \times 1.6 \times 10^{-19}}{2 \times 8.84 \times 10^{-12} \times \frac{1}{1-0.99^{2}} \times 0.99 \times 3 \times 10^{8}}\right| \\
&=0.0121 \mathrm{~T} / \mathrm{m}=1.21 \mathrm{Gs} / \mathrm{cm} .
\end{aligned}
$$



\section{2}

The uniformly distributed charge per unit length in an infinite ion beam of constant circular cross section is $q$. Calculate the force on a single beam ion that is located at radius $r$, assuming that the beam radius $R$ is greater than $r$ and that the ions all have the same velocity $v$.

$(U C$, Berkeley)

\section{Solution:}

Use cylindrical coordinates with the $z$-axis along the axis of the ion beam such that the flow of the ions is in the $+z$ direction. Let $\Sigma^{\prime}$ and $\Sigma$ be the rest frame of the ions and the laboratory frame respectively, the former moving with velocity $v$ relative to the latter in the $+z$ direction. The charge per unit length in $\Sigma$ is $q$. In $\Sigma^{\prime}$ it is given by $q=\gamma\left(\frac{q^{\prime}+\beta j^{\prime}}{c}\right)=\gamma q^{\prime}$, or $q^{\prime}=q / \gamma$, where $\gamma=\left(1-\beta^{2}\right)^{-\frac{1}{2}}, \beta=\frac{v}{c}$. In $\Sigma^{\prime}$ the electronic field is given by Gauss' law $2 \pi E_{r}^{\prime}=\frac{r^{2}}{R^{2}} \frac{q^{\prime}}{\varepsilon_{0}}$ to be

$$
\mathbf{E}^{\prime}=\frac{r q^{\prime}}{2 \pi \varepsilon_{0} R^{2}} \mathbf{e}_{r} \cdot \quad(r<R)
$$

As the ions are stationary,

$$
B^{\prime}=0 \text {. }
$$

Transforming to $\Sigma$ we have $\mathbf{E}_{\perp}=\gamma\left(\mathbf{E}_{\perp}^{\prime}-\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{B}_{\perp}^{\prime}\right)=\gamma \mathbf{E}_{\perp}^{\prime}, E_{\|}=E_{\|}^{\prime}=0$, or

$$
\mathbf{E}=\gamma \mathbf{E}^{\prime}=\frac{r \gamma q^{\prime}}{2 \pi \varepsilon_{0} R^{2}} \mathbf{e}_{r}=\frac{r q}{2 \pi \varepsilon_{0} R^{2}} \mathbf{e}_{r}
$$

and $\mathbf{B}_{\perp}=\gamma\left(\mathbf{B}_{\perp}^{\prime}+\frac{v \times E_{\perp}^{\prime}}{c^{2}}\right)=\gamma \frac{v \times E_{\perp}^{\prime}}{c^{2}}, \mathbf{B}_{\|}=\mathbf{B}_{\|}^{\prime}=0$, or

$$
\mathbf{B}=\gamma \frac{v}{c^{2}} \cdot \frac{r q^{\prime}}{2 \pi \varepsilon_{0} R^{2}} \mathbf{e}_{\theta}=\frac{v}{c} \cdot \frac{r q}{2 \pi \varepsilon_{0} c R^{2}} \mathbf{e}_{\theta} .
$$

Note that, as $r$ is transverse to $\mathbf{v}, r^{\prime}=r$. Hence the total force acting on an ion of charge $Q$ at distance $r<R$ from the axis in the laboratory frame is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{F} &=Q \mathbf{E}+Q \mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{B} \\
&=\left(Q \cdot \frac{q r}{2 \pi \varepsilon_{0} R^{2}}-Q \frac{v^{2}}{c^{2}} \frac{q r}{2 \pi \varepsilon_{0} R^{2}}\right) \mathbf{e}_{r} \\
&=\frac{Q q r}{2 \pi \varepsilon_{0} R^{2}}\left(1-\frac{v^{2}}{c^{2}}\right) \mathbf{e}_{r}=\frac{Q q r}{2 \pi \varepsilon_{0} R^{2} \gamma^{2}} \mathbf{e}_{r} .
\end{aligned}
$$

If $v \ll c$, then $F=\frac{Q g r}{2 \pi \varepsilon_{0} R^{2}} \mathbf{e}_{r}$, which is what one would obtain if both the charge and the ion beam were stationary.

\section{3}

Given a uniform beam of charged particles $q / l$ charges per unit length, moving with velocity $v$, uniformly distributed within a circular cylinder of radius $R$. What is the
(a) electric field $\mathbf{E}$
(b) magnetic field $\mathbf{B}$
(c) energy density
(d) momentum density

of the field throughout space?

\section{Solution:}

(a), (b) Referring to Problems 5011 and 5012, we have

$$
\begin{array}{r}
\mathbf{E}= \begin{cases}\frac{q r}{2 \pi \varepsilon_{0} R^{2} l} \mathbf{e}_{r}, & (r<R) \\
\frac{q}{2 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r l} \mathbf{e}_{r} . & (r>R)\end{cases} \\
\mathbf{B}= \begin{cases}\frac{v q r}{2 \pi \varepsilon_{0} c^{2} R^{2 l}} \mathbf{e}_{\theta}, & (r<R) \\
\frac{v q}{2 \pi \varepsilon_{0} c^{2} r l} \mathbf{e}_{\theta} . & (r>R)\end{cases}
\end{array}
$$

(c) The energy density is

$$
\begin{aligned}
w &=\frac{1}{2}\left(\varepsilon_{0} E^{2}+\frac{1}{\mu_{0}} B^{2}\right) \\
&= \begin{cases}\left(1+\frac{v^{2}}{c^{2}}\right) \frac{q^{2} r^{2}}{8 \pi^{2} \varepsilon_{0} R^{4 / 2}}, & (r<R) \\
\left(1+\frac{v^{2}}{c^{2}}\right) \frac{q^{2}}{8 \pi^{2} \varepsilon_{0} r^{2} l^{2}} & (r>R)\end{cases}
\end{aligned}
$$

(d) The momentum density is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{g} &=\varepsilon_{0} \mathbf{E} \times \mathbf{B} \\
&= \begin{cases}\frac{v q^{2} r^{2}}{4 \pi^{2} \varepsilon_{0} c^{2} R^{4} l^{2}} \mathbf{e}_{z}, & (r<R) \\
\frac{v q^{2}}{4 \pi^{2} \varepsilon_{0} c^{2} r^{2} l^{2}} \mathbf{e}_{z} & (r>R)\end{cases}
\end{aligned}
$$



\section{4}

Calculate the net radial force on an individual electron in an infinitely long cylindrical beam of relativistic electrons of constant density $n$ moving with uniform velocity $\mathbf{v}$. Consider both the electric and magnetic forces.

(Wisconsin)

\section{Solution:}

The charge density of the electron beam is $\rho=-e n$. As shown in Problem 5011, the net radial force on an individual electron is

$$
\mathbf{F}=-\frac{e \rho r}{2 \varepsilon_{0} \gamma^{2}} \mathbf{e}_{r}=\frac{e^{2} n r}{2 \pi \varepsilon_{0} \gamma^{2}} \mathbf{e}_{r}
$$

where

$$
\gamma=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-v^{2} / c^{2}}}
$$

\section{5}

A perfectly conducting sphere of radius $R$ moves with constant velocity $\mathbf{v}=v \mathbf{e}_{x}(v \ll c)$ through a uniform magnetic field $\mathrm{B}=B \mathbf{e}_{y}$. Find the surface charge density induced on the sphere to lowest order in $v / c$.

\section{Solution:}

Let $\Sigma^{\prime}$ and $\Sigma$ be the rest frame of the conducting sphere and the laboratory frame respectively. In $\Sigma$ we have $B=B \mathbf{e}_{y}, \mathbf{E}=0$. Transforming to $\Sigma^{\prime}$ we have

$$
\begin{gathered}
E_{\|}^{\prime}=E_{\|}=0, \quad E_{\perp}^{\prime}=\gamma\left(\mathbf{E}_{\perp}+\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{B}_{\perp}\right)=\gamma v B \mathbf{e}_{z} \\
B_{\|}^{\prime}=B_{\|}=0, \quad B_{\perp}^{\prime}=\gamma\left(\mathbf{B}_{\perp}-\frac{\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{E}_{\perp}}{c^{2}}\right)=\gamma B \mathbf{e}_{y} .
\end{gathered}
$$

\section{Hence}

$$
\mathbf{E}^{\prime}=\gamma v B \mathbf{e}_{z}, \quad \mathbf{B}^{\prime}=\gamma B \mathbf{e}_{y} .
$$

In the lowest order approximation, $\gamma=\left(1-\frac{v^{2}}{c^{2}}\right)^{-1 / 2} \approx 1$, one has

$$
\mathbf{E}^{\prime} \approx v B \mathbf{e}_{z}, \quad \mathbf{B}^{\prime}=B \mathbf{e}_{y} .
$$

In $\Sigma^{\prime}$ the electric field external to the sphere $\mathbf{E}^{\prime}$ is uniform so the potential outside the sphere is (see Problem 1065)

$$
\varphi^{\prime}=-E^{\prime} r \cos \theta+\frac{E^{\prime} R^{3}}{r^{2}} \cos \theta,
$$

with $\theta$ as shown in Fig. 5.7.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_6a2dacf5647d8430e732g-587.jpg?height=293&width=300&top_left_y=450&top_left_x=520)

Fig. $5.7$

The surface charge density on the conductor is given by the boundary condition for D:

$$
\sigma^{\prime}=-\left.\varepsilon_{0} \frac{\partial \varphi^{\prime}}{\partial r}\right|_{r=R}=3 \varepsilon_{0} v B \cos \theta .
$$

On transforming back to $\Sigma$, as the relative velocity of $\Sigma^{\prime}$ is along the $x$ direction, the angle $\theta$ remains unchanged. Hence the surface charge density induced on the sphere to lowest order in $v / c$ is

$$
\sigma=\gamma \sigma^{\prime} \approx \sigma^{\prime}=3 \varepsilon_{0} v B \cos \theta .
$$

\section{6}

Let a particle of charge $q$ and rest mass $m$ be released with zero initial velocity in a region of space containing an electric field $\mathbf{E}$ in the $y$ direction and a magnetic field $B$ in the $z$ direction.

(a) Describe the conditions necessary for the existence of a Lorentz frame in which (1) $E=0$ and (2) $B=0$.

(b) Describe the motion that would ensue in the original frame if case

(a) (1) attains.

(c) Solve for the momentum as a function of time in the frame with $B=0$ for case $(a)(2)$ 

\section{Solution:}

(a) Let $\Sigma$ be the laboratory frame and $\Sigma^{\prime}$ be a frame moving with relative velocity $v$ along the $x$ direction. In $\Sigma$ we have

$$
\mathbf{E}=E \mathbf{e}_{y}, \quad \mathbf{B}=B \mathbf{e}_{z} .
$$

Lorentz transformation gives the electromagnetic field in $\Sigma^{\prime}$ as

$$
\begin{gathered}
E_{x}^{\prime}=E_{x}=0, \quad E_{y}^{\prime}=\gamma\left(E_{y}-v B_{z}\right)=\gamma(E-v B), \quad E_{z}^{\prime}=\gamma\left(E_{x}+v B_{y}\right)=0, \\
B_{x}^{\prime}=B_{x}=0, \quad B_{y}^{\prime}=\gamma\left(B_{y}+\frac{v}{c^{2}} E_{z}\right)=0, \\
B_{z}^{\prime}=\gamma\left(B_{z}-\frac{v}{c^{2}} E_{y}\right)=\gamma\left(B-\frac{v}{c^{2}} E\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

(1) For $E^{\prime}=0$ in $\Sigma^{\prime}$ we require that

$$
E-v B=0,
$$

or $v=\frac{E}{B}$. However, as $v \leq c$, for such a frame $\Sigma^{\prime}$ to exist we require that $E \leq c B$

(2) For $B^{\prime}=0$ in $\Sigma^{\prime}$, we require that $B-\frac{v}{c^{2}} E=0$, or $v=\frac{c^{2} B}{E}$. Then for such a frame $\Sigma^{\prime}$ to exist we require that

$$
c B \leq E .
$$

(b) If $\mathbf{E}^{\prime}=0$, the motion of the charge $q$ in $\Sigma^{\prime}$ is described by

$$
\begin{gathered}
\frac{d}{d t^{\prime}}\left(\frac{m \mathbf{u}^{\prime}}{\sqrt{1-u^{\prime 2} / c^{2}}}\right)=q \mathbf{u}^{\prime} \times \mathbf{B}^{\prime}, \\
\frac{d}{d t^{\prime}}\left(\frac{m c^{2}}{\sqrt{1-u^{\prime 2} / c^{2}}}\right)=q\left(\mathbf{u}^{\prime} \times \mathbf{B}^{\prime}\right) \cdot \mathbf{u}^{\prime}=0,
\end{gathered}
$$

where $\mathbf{u}^{\prime}$ is the velocity of the particle in $\Sigma^{\prime}$. Equation (2) means that

$$
\frac{m c^{2}}{\sqrt{1-\frac{u^{\prime 2}}{c^{2}}}}=\text { constant } \text {. }
$$

Hence $u^{\prime}=$ constant as well. This implies that the magnitude of the velocity of the particle does not change, while its direction changes. As the initial velocity of the particle in $\Sigma$ is zero, the velocity of the particle in $\Sigma^{\prime}$ at the initial time $t^{\prime}=0$ is by the transformation equations

$$
u_{x}^{\prime}=\frac{u_{x}-v}{1-\frac{v u_{x}}{c^{2}}}=-v, \quad u_{y}^{\prime}=\frac{u_{y}}{\gamma\left(1-\frac{v u_{x}}{c^{2}}\right)}=0, \quad u_{z}^{\prime}=0
$$

to be

$$
\mathbf{u}_{0}^{\prime}=-v \mathbf{e}_{x}=-\frac{E}{B} \mathbf{e}_{x} .
$$

Thus the magnitude of the velocity of the particle will always be $u^{\prime}=\frac{E}{B}$, and we have

$$
\sqrt{1-u^{\prime 2} / c^{2}}=\frac{\sqrt{B^{2} c^{2}-E^{2}}}{B c}=\text { constant }
$$

Then Eq. (1) reduces to

$$
\dot{\mathbf{u}}^{\prime}=\frac{q}{m} \sqrt{1-u^{\prime 2} / c^{2}} \mathbf{u}^{\prime} \times \mathbf{B}^{\prime}
$$

From the transformation equations for $B$ we have $B^{\prime}=\frac{1}{c} \sqrt{B^{2} c^{2}-E^{2}} \mathbf{e}_{z}$. Hence Eq. (3) gives rise to

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\dot{u}_{x}^{\prime}=\omega u_{y}^{\prime}, \\
&\dot{u}_{y}^{\prime}=-\omega u_{x}^{\prime}, \\
&\dot{u}_{z}^{\prime}=0
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
\omega=\frac{q B^{\prime} \sqrt{1-u^{\prime 2} / c^{2}}}{m}=\frac{q\left(c^{2} B^{2}-E^{2}\right)}{c^{2} m B} .
$$

Equation (6) shows that $u_{z}^{\prime}=$ constant. As $u_{z}^{\prime}=0$ at $t^{\prime}=0, u_{z}^{\prime}=0$ for all times.

$(4)+(5) \times i$ gives

$$
\dot{u}_{x}^{\prime}+i \dot{u}_{y}^{\prime}=-i \omega\left(u_{x}^{\prime}+i u_{y}^{\prime}\right)
$$

or

$$
\xi=-i \omega \xi
$$

where

$$
\xi=u_{x}^{\prime}+i u_{y}^{\prime}
$$



\section{The solution is}

$$
\xi=-u_{0}^{\prime} e^{-i \omega t^{\prime}}
$$

or

$$
u_{x}^{\prime}=u_{0}^{\prime} \cos \left(\omega t^{\prime}\right), \quad u_{y}^{\prime}=-u_{0}^{\prime} \sin \left(\omega t^{\prime}\right)
$$

where $u_{0}^{\prime}$ is a constant.

As $u_{0}^{\prime}=\frac{E}{B}$ at $t^{\prime}=0$ we find that

$$
u_{x}^{\prime}=\frac{E}{B} \cos \left(\omega t^{\prime}\right), \quad u_{y}^{\prime}=-\frac{E}{B} \sin \left(\omega t^{\prime}\right) .
$$

These equations show that the particle will undergo circular motion in the $x y$ plane with a radius

$$
R=\frac{u^{\prime}}{\omega}=\frac{E}{B \omega}=\frac{c^{2} m E}{q\left(c^{2} B^{2}-E^{2}\right)} .
$$

In $\Sigma$, because of Lorentz contraction in the $x$ direction, the orbit is an ellipse with the minor axis along the $x$-axis.

(c) Consider a frame $\Sigma^{\prime}$ in which $B^{\prime}=0$. Let $\mathbf{p}^{\prime}$ be the momentum of the particle. The equation of motion is then

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_6a2dacf5647d8430e732g-590.jpg?height=103&width=194&top_left_y=1056&top_left_x=569)

The quantity $E^{2}-c^{2} B^{2}$ is Lorentz invariant as shown in Problem 5008. Hence $\mathbf{E}^{\prime}=\sqrt{E^{2}-c^{2} B^{2}} \mathbf{e}_{y}$, using also the result of (a). Then the equation of motion has component equations

$$
\begin{gathered}
\frac{d p_{x}^{\prime}}{d t^{\prime}}=\frac{d p_{z}^{\prime}}{d t^{\prime}}=0, \\
\frac{d p_{y}^{\prime}}{d t^{\prime}}=q \sqrt{E^{2}-c^{2} B^{2}} .
\end{gathered}
$$

Equation (7) shows that both $p_{x}^{\prime}$ and $p_{z}^{\prime}$ are constant, being independent of time. The particle is initially at rest in $\Sigma$, so its initial velocity is opposite that of $\Sigma^{\prime}$, i.e., $\mathbf{u}_{0}^{\prime}=-\frac{c^{2} B}{E} \mathbf{e}_{x}$, as shown in (a)(2). Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
p_{x}^{\prime} &=\frac{m u_{0}^{\prime}}{\sqrt{1-u^{\prime 2} / c^{2}}}=\frac{c^{2} m B}{\sqrt{E^{2}-c^{2} B^{2}}} \\
p_{z}^{\prime} &=0
\end{aligned}
$$



\section{Equation (8) gives}

$$
p_{y}\left(t^{\prime}\right)=q \sqrt{E^{2}-c^{2} B^{2}} t^{\prime},
$$

where we have used the initial condition $u_{0 y}^{\prime}=0$ at $t^{\prime}=0$.

\section{7}

Consider an arbitrary plane electromagnetic wave propagating in vacuum in $x$-direction. Let $A(x-c t)$ be the vector potential of the wave; there are no sources, so adopt a gauge in which the scalar potential is identically zero. Assume that the wave does not extend throughout all spaces, in particular $A=0$ for sufficiently large values of $x-c t$. The wave strikes a particle with charge $e$ which is initially at rest and accelerates it to a velocity which may be relativistic.

(a) Show that $A_{x}=0$.

(b) Show that $\mathbf{p}_{\perp}=-e \mathbf{A}$, where $\mathbf{p}_{\perp}$ is the particle momentum in the $y z$ plane. (Note: Since this is a relativistic problem, do not solve it with non-relativistic mechanics.)

$(U C$, Berkeley)

\section{Solution:}

(a) As $\mathbf{A}=\mathbf{A}(x-c t)$

$$
\frac{\partial \mathbf{A}}{\partial x}=\frac{\partial \mathbf{A}}{\partial(x-c t)}, \quad \frac{\partial \mathbf{A}}{\partial t}=-c \frac{\partial \mathbf{A}}{\partial(x-c t)} .
$$

With the gauge condition $\varphi=0$,

$$
\mathbf{E}=-\nabla \varphi-\frac{\partial \mathbf{A}}{\partial t}=-\frac{\partial \mathbf{A}}{\partial t} .
$$

As plane electromagnetic waves are transverse, $E_{x}=0$. Thus

$$
-\frac{\partial A_{x}}{\partial t}=\frac{c \partial A_{x}}{\partial(x-c t)}=0
$$

showing that $A_{x}(x-c t)=$ constant.

Since the wave does not extend throughout all space, the vector potential vanishes for sufficiently large values of $x-c t$. Hence the above constant is zero, i.e., $A_{x}=0$ at all points of space. (b) Let $\mathbf{r}$ be the displacement of the charged particle at time $t$ and write the vector potential as $\mathbf{A}(\mathbf{r}, t)$. We have

$$
\frac{d \mathbf{A}}{d t}=\frac{\partial A}{\partial t}+\sum_{j=1}^{3} \frac{\partial \mathbf{A}}{\partial x_{j}} \frac{\partial x_{j}}{\partial t}=\frac{\partial \mathbf{A}}{\partial t}+(\mathbf{v} \cdot \nabla) \mathbf{A} .
$$

The equation of motion of a particle of charge $e$ and momentum $\mathbf{p}$ in the electromagnetic field is

$$
\frac{d \mathbf{p}}{d t}=e(\mathbf{E}+\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{B}) .
$$

Treating $\mathbf{r}$ and $\mathbf{v}$ as independent variables, we have

$$
\mathbf{v} \times(\nabla \times \mathbf{A})=\nabla(\mathbf{v} \cdot \mathbf{A})-(\mathbf{v} \cdot \nabla) \mathbf{A}
$$

Equations (1)-(3) give

$$
\frac{d \mathbf{p}}{d t}=e \nabla(\mathbf{v} \cdot \mathbf{A})-e \frac{d \mathbf{A}}{d t} .
$$

Consider the transverse component of the particle momentum, $\mathbf{p}_{\perp}=p_{y} \mathbf{e}_{y}+$ $p_{z} \mathbf{e}_{z}$.

The vector potential $\mathbf{A}(x-c t)$ of the plane electromagnetic wave is independent of the coordinates $y$ and $z$, and has no longitudinal component (see (a)). As $\mathbf{r}$ and $\mathbf{v}$ are to be treated as independent variables also, we have

$$
\frac{\partial}{\partial y}(\mathbf{v} \cdot \mathbf{A})=v_{y} \frac{\partial A_{y}}{\partial y}+v_{z} \frac{\partial A_{z}}{\partial z}=0
$$

and similarly $\frac{\partial}{\partial z}(\mathbf{v} \cdot \mathbf{A})=0$. Hence

$$
\frac{d \mathbf{p}_{\perp}}{d t}=-e \frac{d \mathbf{A}_{\perp}}{d t} .
$$

\section{Integration gives}

$$
\mathbf{p}_{\perp}=-e \mathbf{A}_{\perp}+\mathbf{C} \text {. }
$$

Since the initial velocity of the particle is zero, the constant $\mathbf{C}$ is zero. Furthermore with $A_{x}=0, \mathbf{A}_{\perp}=\mathrm{A}$. So we can write the above as

$$
\mathbf{p}_{\perp}=-v \mathbf{A} .
$$



\section{ELECTROMAGNETIC FIELD OF A CHARGED PARTICLE (5018-5025)}

\section{8}

Show that the electromagnetic field of a particle of charge $q$ moving with constant velocity $\mathbf{v}$ is given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
& E_{x}=\frac{q}{\chi} \gamma(x-v t), \quad B_{x}=0, \\
& E_{y}=\frac{q}{\chi} \gamma y, \quad B_{y}=-\frac{q}{\chi} \beta \gamma z, \\
& E_{z}=\frac{q}{\chi} \gamma z, \quad B_{z}=\frac{q}{\chi} \beta \gamma y,
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
\begin{gathered}
\beta=\frac{v}{c}, \quad \gamma=\left(1-\frac{v^{2}}{c^{2}}\right)^{-\frac{1}{2}}, \\
\chi=\left\{\gamma^{2}(x-v t)^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}\right\}^{3 / 2},
\end{gathered}
$$

and we have chosen the $x$-axis along $\mathbf{v}$ (note that we use units such that the proportionality constant in Coulomb's law is $K=1$ ).

$(S U N Y, B u f f a l o)$

\section{Solution:}

Let $\Sigma$ be the observer's frame and $\Sigma^{\prime}$ the rest frame of the particle. In the units used we have in $\Sigma^{\prime}$

$$
\mathbf{E}^{\prime}\left(\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right)=\frac{q \mathbf{x}^{\prime}}{r^{\prime 3}}, \quad \mathbf{B}^{\prime}\left(\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right)=0,
$$

where

$$
r^{\prime}=\left|\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right| .
$$

The Lorentz transformation for time-space between $\Sigma$ and $\Sigma^{\prime}$ is given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
&x^{\prime}=\gamma(x-v t), \\
&y^{\prime}=y, \\
&z^{\prime}=z,
\end{aligned}
$$

so that

$$
r^{\prime 2}=x^{\prime 2}+y^{\prime 2}+z^{\prime 2}=\gamma^{2}(x-v t)^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2} .
$$



\section{The (inverse) Lorentz transformation for electromagnetic field gives}

$$
\begin{aligned}
&E_{x}=E_{x}^{\prime}=\frac{q x^{\prime}}{r^{\prime 3}}=\frac{q}{\chi} \gamma(x-v t), \\
&E_{y}=\gamma\left(E_{y}^{\prime}+\beta B_{z}^{\prime}\right)=\frac{q y}{\chi} \gamma, \\
&E_{z}=\gamma\left(E_{z}^{\prime}-\beta B_{y}^{\prime}\right)=\frac{q z}{\chi} \gamma, \\
&B_{x}=B_{x}^{\prime}=0, \\
&B_{y}=\gamma\left(B_{y}^{\prime}-\beta E_{z}^{\prime}\right)=-\frac{q}{\chi} \beta \gamma z, \\
&B_{z}=\gamma\left(B_{z}^{\prime}+\beta E_{y}^{\prime}\right)=\frac{q}{\chi} \beta \gamma y .
\end{aligned}
$$

\section{9}

(a) Consider two positrons in a beam at SLAC. The beam has energy of about $50 \mathrm{GeV}\left(\gamma \approx 10^{5}\right)$. In the beam frame (rest frame) they are separated by a distance $d$, and positron $\mathrm{e}_{2}^{+}$is traveling directly ahead of $\mathrm{e}_{1}^{+}$, as shown in Fig. 5.8. Write down expressions at $\mathrm{e}_{1}^{+}$giving the effect of $e_{2}^{+}$. Specifically, give the following vectors: $\mathbf{E}, \mathbf{B}$, the Lorentz force $\mathbf{F}$, and the acceleration a. Do this in two reference frames:

1. the rest frame, 2. the laboratory frame.

The results will differ by various relativistic factors. Give intuitive explanations of these factors.

(b) The problem is the same as in part (a) except this time the two positrons are traveling side by side as sketched in Fig. 5.9.

\section{Solution:}

(a) Let $\Sigma^{\prime}$ and $\Sigma$ be the beam rest frame and the laboratory frame respectively. In $\Sigma^{\prime}$ the effects exerted by $e_{2}^{+}$on $e_{1}^{+}$are

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{E}^{\prime} &=-\frac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}} \frac{e}{d^{2}} \mathbf{e}_{z}, \\
\mathbf{B}^{\prime} &=0, \\
\mathbf{F}^{\prime} &=e \mathbf{E}^{\prime}=-\frac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}} \frac{e^{2}}{d^{2}} \mathbf{e}_{z}, \\
\mathbf{a}^{\prime} &=\frac{\mathbf{F}^{\prime}}{m}=-\frac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} m} \frac{e^{2}}{d^{2}} \mathbf{e}_{z} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus in $\Sigma^{\prime}, e_{1}^{+}$is a nonrelativistic particle that will undergo rectilinear accelerated motion under the action of the electrostatic field $\mathbf{E}^{\prime}$ established by $\mathrm{e}_{2}^{+}$. $B_{\|}^{\prime}$, gives

The Lorentz transformation for electromagnetic field $E_{\|}=E_{\|}^{\prime}, B_{\|}=$

$$
\mathbf{E}=\mathbf{E}^{\prime}=-\frac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}} \frac{e}{d^{2}} \mathbf{e}_{z}, \quad \mathbf{B}=0 .
$$

Hence the force on $e_{1}^{+}$is

$$
\mathbf{F}=e \mathbf{E}=-\frac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}} \frac{e^{2}}{d^{2}} \mathbf{e}_{z}=\mathbf{\Sigma}^{\prime} .
$$

As $\gamma=10^{5}, e_{1}^{+}$is a relativistic particle in $\Sigma$ and must satisfy the relativistic equations of motion

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{m \mathbf{v}}{\sqrt{1-v^{2} / c^{2}}}\right)=\mathbf{F}, \quad \text { or } \quad m c \frac{d}{d t}(\gamma \beta)=F, \\
&\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{m c^{2}}{\sqrt{1-v^{2} / c^{2}}}\right)=\mathbf{F} \cdot \mathbf{v}, \quad \text { or } \quad m c \frac{d \gamma}{d t}=F \beta
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\beta=\frac{v}{c}, \gamma=\left(1-\beta^{2}\right)^{-\frac{1}{2}}$, since $\mathbf{F}=F \mathbf{e}_{z}, \mathbf{v}=v \mathbf{e}_{z}$. We then have

$$
a=c \frac{d \beta}{d t}=\frac{c}{\gamma}\left[\frac{d}{d t}(\gamma \beta)-\beta \frac{d \gamma}{d t}\right]=\frac{1}{m \gamma}\left(F-F \beta^{2}\right)=\frac{F}{m \gamma^{3}},
$$

or

$$
\mathbf{a}=\frac{d \mathbf{v}}{d t}=\frac{\mathbf{F}}{m \gamma^{3}}=-\frac{e^{2}}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r^{3} m d^{2}} \mathbf{e}_{z}=\frac{\mathbf{a}}{\gamma^{3}} .
$$

It follows that when the motion of the two positrons is as shown in Fig. 5.8, the electromagnetic field and the Lorentz force are the same in $\Sigma$ and $\Sigma^{\prime}$. However, due to the relativistic effect the acceleration of $e_{1}^{+}$in the laboratory frame is only $\frac{1}{\gamma^{s}}$ times that in the rest frame. As $\frac{1}{\gamma^{s}} \approx 10^{-15}$, $a$ is extremely small. In other words, the influence of the force exerted by a neighboring collinear charge on a charge moving with high speed will be small. The whole beam travels together in a state of high velocity and high energy.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_6a2dacf5647d8430e732g-595.jpg?height=96&width=422&top_left_y=1724&top_left_x=463)

Fig. $5.8$ (b) In the case shown in Fig. $5.9$, we have in the rest frame $\Sigma^{\prime}$ the various vectors at $e_{1}^{+}$:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{\Sigma}^{\prime} &=-\frac{e}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} d^{2}} \mathbf{e}_{z}, \quad \mathbf{B}^{\prime}=0, \\
\mathbf{\Sigma}^{\prime} &=e \mathbf{E}^{\prime}=-\frac{e^{2}}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} d^{2}} \mathbf{e}_{z} \\
\mathbf{a}^{\prime} &=\frac{\mathbf{F}}{m}=-\frac{e^{2}}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} m d^{2}} \mathbf{e}_{z} .
\end{aligned}
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_6a2dacf5647d8430e732g-596.jpg?height=287&width=363&top_left_y=602&top_left_x=384)

Fig. $5.9$

\section{In the laboratory frame $\Sigma$, as}

$$
\begin{gathered}
\mathbf{E}_{\perp}=\gamma\left(\mathbf{E}_{\perp}^{\prime}-\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{B}_{\perp}^{\prime}\right), \\
\mathbf{B}_{\perp}=\gamma\left(\mathbf{B}_{\perp}^{\prime}+\frac{\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{E}_{\perp}^{\prime}}{c^{2}}\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\mathbf{E}=\gamma \mathbf{E}^{\prime}=-\frac{\gamma e}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} d^{2}} \mathbf{e}_{x}, \\
&\mathbf{B}=\gamma \frac{v}{c^{2}} E^{\prime} \mathbf{e}_{y}=-\frac{\gamma v e}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} c^{2} d^{2}} \mathbf{e}_{y}, \\
&\mathbf{F}=e(\mathbf{E}+\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{B})=-\frac{e^{2}}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} d^{2} \gamma} \mathbf{e}_{x}=\frac{\mathbf{F}^{\prime}}{\gamma} .
\end{aligned}
$$

In this case $\boldsymbol{F} \cdot \mathbf{v}=0$, so that $\gamma=$ constant and

$$
a=\frac{m c}{m \gamma} \frac{d}{d t}(\gamma \beta)=\frac{F}{m \gamma},
$$

or

$$
\mathbf{a}=\frac{\mathbf{F}}{m \gamma}=-\frac{e^{2}}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} d^{2} m \gamma^{2}} \mathbf{e}_{x}=\frac{\mathbf{a}^{\prime}}{\gamma^{2}} .
$$

These results show that when the two positrons are traveling side by side, all the vectors in $\Sigma$, as compared with the corresponding vectors in $\boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{\prime}$, will involve the Lorentz factor $\gamma$ which is a constant of the motion. In the laboratory frame, both the electric and magnetic fields exist, the former being increased by $\gamma$ from that in the rest frame. As to the effects of $\mathbf{E}$ and $B$ on $e_{1}^{+}$, they tend to cancel each other, which reduces the force on the acceleration of $e_{1}^{+}$by factors $\frac{1}{\gamma}$ and $\frac{1}{\gamma^{2}}$ respectively, as compared with those in the rest frame.

\section{0}

In Fig. $5.10$ a point charge $e$ moves with constant velocity $v$ in the $z$ direction so that at time $t$ it is at the point $Q$ with coordinates $x=0$, $y=0, z=v t$. Find at the time $t$ and at the point $P$ with coordinates $x=b, y=0, z=0$ (see Fig. 5.10)
(a) the scalar potential $\phi$,
(b) the vector potential A,
(c) the electric field in the $x$ direction, $E_{x}$.

(Wisconsin)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_6a2dacf5647d8430e732g-597.jpg?height=267&width=484&top_left_y=1094&top_left_x=432)

Fig. $5.10$

\section{Solution:}

by
(a) The Linard-Wiechert potentials at $P$ due to the charge are given

$$
\phi=\frac{e}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}\left[r-\frac{\mathbf{v}}{c} \cdot \mathbf{r}\right]}, \quad \mathbf{A}=\frac{e \mathbf{v}}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} c^{2}\left[r-\frac{\mathbf{v}}{c} \cdot \mathbf{r}\right]}
$$

where $\mathbf{r}$ is the radius vector from the retarded position of the charge to the field point $P$, i.e.,

$$
\mathbf{r}=b \mathbf{e}_{x}-v\left(t-\frac{r}{c}\right) \mathbf{e}_{z}=b \mathbf{e}_{x}-v t^{\prime} \mathbf{e}_{z}
$$

with

$$
t^{\prime}=t-\frac{r}{c} .
$$

Thus

$$
r^{2}=r \cdot r=b^{2}+v^{2}\left(t-\frac{r}{c}\right)^{2}=b^{2}+v^{2}\left(t^{2}-\frac{2 r t}{c}+\frac{r^{2}}{c^{2}}\right)
$$

or

$$
\left(1-\frac{v^{2}}{c^{2}}\right) r^{2}+2 \frac{v^{2} t}{c} r-b^{2}-v^{2} t^{2}=0 .
$$

This is the retardation condition, with the solutions

$$
r=\frac{-\beta v t \pm \sqrt{\left(1-\beta^{2}\right) b^{2}+v^{2} t^{2}}}{1-\beta^{2}}
$$

where $\beta=\frac{v}{c}$.

However the upper sign is to be taken since $r \geq 0$. As $v=v e_{z}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
r-\frac{\mathbf{v} \cdot \mathbf{r}}{c} &=r+\frac{v^{2} t^{\prime}}{c}=r+v \beta\left(t-\frac{r}{c}\right)=\left(1-\beta^{2}\right) r+v \beta t \\
&=\sqrt{\left(1-\beta^{2}\right) b^{2}+v^{2} t^{2}} .
\end{aligned}
$$

The scalar potential $\phi$ is then

$$
\phi=\frac{e}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} \sqrt{\left(1-\beta^{2}\right) b^{2}+v^{2} t^{2}}}
$$

(b) The vector potential $A$ is

$$
\mathbf{A}=\frac{e v}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} c^{2} \sqrt{\left(1-\beta^{2}\right) b^{2}+v^{2} t^{2}}} \mathbf{e}_{z} .
$$

(c) The electric field at $P$ is obtained by differentiating the LinardWiechert potentials:

$$
\mathbf{E}(t)=-\nabla \phi-\frac{\partial \mathbf{A}}{\partial t} .
$$

For the spatial differentiation, $b$ is to be first replaced by $x$. We then have

$$
(\nabla \phi)_{b}=\left(\frac{\partial \phi}{\partial x}\right)_{b} \mathbf{e}_{x}=-\frac{e\left(1-\beta^{2}\right) b}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}\left[\left(1-\beta^{2}\right) b^{2}+v^{2} t^{2}\right]^{3 / 2}} \mathbf{e}_{x}
$$

As $A$ is in the $z$-direction, it does not contribute to $E_{x}$. Hence

$$
E_{x}=\frac{e\left(1-\beta^{2}\right) b}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}\left[\left(1-\beta^{2}\right) b^{2}+v^{2} t^{2}\right]^{3 / 2}} .
$$

\section{1}

For a particle of charge $e$ moving non-relativistically, find

(a) The time-averaged power radiated per unit solid angle, $d P / d \Omega$, in terms of velocity $\beta c$, acceleration $\dot{\beta} c$, and the unit vector $\mathbf{n}^{\prime}$ from the charge toward the observer;

(b) $d P / d \Omega$, if the particle moves as $z(t)=a \cos \left(\omega_{0} t\right)$

(c) $d P / d \Omega$ for circular motion of radius $R$ in the $x y$ plane with constant angular frequency $\omega_{0}$.

(d) Sketch the angular distribution of the radiation in each case.

(e) Qualitatively, how is $d P / d \Omega$ changed if the motion is relativistic? (Princeton)

\section{Solution:} by

(a) For a non-relativistic particle of charge $e$ the radiation field is given

$$
\begin{gathered}
\mathbf{E}=\frac{e \mathbf{n}^{\prime} \times\left(\mathbf{n}^{\prime} \times \dot{\boldsymbol{\beta}} c\right)}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} c^{2} r}=\frac{e}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} c r} \mathbf{n}^{\prime} \times\left(\mathbf{n}^{\prime} \times \dot{\boldsymbol{\beta}}\right), \\
\mathbf{B}=\frac{1}{c} \mathbf{n}^{\prime} \times \mathbf{E}
\end{gathered}
$$

where $r$ is the distance of the observer from the charge. The Poynting vector at the observer is then

$$
\mathbf{N}=\mathbf{E} \times \mathbf{H}=\frac{1}{\mu_{0}} \mathbf{E} \times \mathbf{B}=\frac{1}{\mu_{0} c} E^{2} \mathbf{n}^{\prime}=\frac{e^{2}}{16 \pi^{2} \varepsilon_{0} c r^{2}}\left|\mathbf{n}^{\prime} \times\left(\mathbf{n}^{\prime} \times \dot{\boldsymbol{\beta}}\right)\right|^{2} \mathbf{n}^{\prime} .
$$

Let $\theta$ be the angle between $\mathbf{n}^{\prime}$ and $\dot{\boldsymbol{\beta}}$, then

$$
\frac{d P}{d \Omega}=\frac{\mathbf{N} \cdot \mathbf{n}^{\prime}}{r^{-2}}=\frac{e^{2}}{16 \pi^{2} \varepsilon_{0} c}|\dot{\boldsymbol{\beta}}|^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta .
$$

This result is not changed by time averging unless the motion of the charge is periodic. (b) If $z=a \cos \left(\omega_{0} t\right)$, then $\dot{\beta} c=\ddot{z}=-a \omega_{0}^{2} \cos \left(\omega_{0} t\right)$ and as $\frac{1}{T} \int_{0}^{T} \cos ^{2}\left(\omega_{0} t\right) d t=\frac{1}{2}$, where $T$ is the period,

Hence

$$
\left\langle(\dot{\beta} c)^{2}\right\rangle=\frac{1}{2} Q^{2} \omega_{0}^{4} .
$$

$$
\frac{d P}{d \Omega}=\frac{e^{2} a^{2} \omega_{0}^{4}}{32 \pi^{2} \varepsilon_{0} c^{3}} \sin ^{2} \theta
$$

(c) The circular motion of the particle in the $x y$ plane may be considered as superposition of two mutually perpendicular harmonic oscillations:

$$
\mathbf{R}\left(t^{\prime}\right)=R \cos \left(\omega_{0} t^{\prime}\right) \mathbf{e}_{x}+R \sin \left(\omega_{0} t^{\prime}\right) \mathbf{e}_{y} .
$$

In spherical coordinates let the observer have radius vector $r(r, \theta, \varphi)$ from the center of the circle, which is also the origin of the coordinate system. The angles between $\mathbf{r}$ or $\mathbf{n}^{\prime}$ and $\dot{\beta}$ for the two oscillations are given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\cos \theta_{1}=\sin \theta \cos \varphi, \\
&\cos \theta_{2}=\sin \theta \cos \left(\frac{\pi}{2}-\varphi\right)=\sin \theta \sin \varphi .
\end{aligned}
$$

Using the results of (b) we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{d P}{d \Omega} &=\frac{e^{2} R^{2} \omega_{0}^{4}}{32 \pi^{2} \varepsilon_{0} c^{3}}\left(\sin ^{2} \theta_{1}+\sin ^{2} \theta_{2}\right) \\
&=\frac{e^{2} R^{2} \omega_{0}^{4}}{32 \pi^{2} \varepsilon_{0} c^{3}}\left(1+\cos ^{2} \theta\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

(d) For the cases (a) and (b), the curves $\rho=\frac{d P}{d \Omega}$ vs. $\theta$ are sketched in Figs. $5.11$ and $5.12$ respectively, where $z$ is the direction of $\dot{\beta}$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_6a2dacf5647d8430e732g-600.jpg?height=495&width=533&top_left_y=1323&top_left_x=384)

Fig. $5.11$ 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_6a2dacf5647d8430e732g-601.jpg?height=610&width=391&top_left_y=169&top_left_x=463)

Fig. $5.12$

(e) For $\beta \approx 0$, the direction of maximum intensity is along $\theta=\frac{\pi}{2}$. As $\beta \rightarrow 1$, the direction of maximum intensity tends more and more toward the direction $\theta=0$, i.e., the direction of $\dot{\beta}$. In fact the radiation will be concentrated mainly in a cone with $\Delta \theta \sim \frac{1}{\gamma}$ about the direction of $\dot{\beta}$. However there is no radiation exactly along that direction.

\section{2}

erenkov radiation is emitted by a high energy charged particle which moves through a medium with a velocity greater than the velocity of electromagnetic wave propagation in the medium.

(a) Derive the relationship between the particle velocity $v=\beta c$, the index of refraction $n$ of the medium, and the angle $\theta$ at which the erenkov radiation is emitted relative to the line of flight of the particle.

(b) Hydrogen gas at one atmosphere and at $20^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ has an index of refraction $n=1+1.35 \times 10^{-4}$. What is the minimum kinetic energy in $\mathrm{MeV}$ which an electron (of rest mass $0.5 \mathrm{MeV} / \mathrm{c}^{2}$ ) would need in order to emit erenkov radiation in traversing a medium of hydrogen gas at $20^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and one atmosphere?

\section{(c) A Cerenkov radiation particle detector is made by fitting a long pipe of one atmosphere, $20^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ hydrogen gas with an optical system capable}

of detecting the emitted light and of measuring the angle of emission $\theta$ to an accuracy of $\delta \theta=10^{-3}$ radian. A beam of charged particles with momentum of $100 \mathrm{GeV} / \mathrm{c}$ are passed through the counter. Since the momentum is known, the measurement of the Cerenkov angle is, in effect, a measurement of the particle rest mass $m_{0}$. For particles with $m_{0}$ near $1 \mathrm{GeV} / \mathrm{c}^{2}$, and to first order in small quantities, what is the fractional error (i.e., $\delta m_{0} / m_{0}$ ) in the determination of $m_{0}$ with the erenkov counter?

(CUSPEA)

\section{Solution:}

(a) As shown in Fig. 5.13, the radiation emitted by the charge at $Q^{\prime}$ at time $t^{\prime}$ arrives at $P$ at time $t$ when the charge is at Q. As the radiation propagates at the speed $c / n$ and the particle has speed $v$ where $v>c / n$, we have

$$
\mathrm{Q}^{\prime} \mathrm{P}=\frac{c}{n}\left(t-t^{\prime}\right), \quad \mathrm{Q}^{\prime} \mathrm{Q}=v\left(t-t^{\prime}\right),
$$

or

$$
\frac{\mathrm{Q}^{\prime} \mathrm{P}}{\mathrm{Q}^{\prime} \mathrm{Q}}=\cos \theta=\frac{c}{v n}=\frac{1}{\beta n},
$$

where $\beta=\frac{v}{c}$. At all the points intermediate between $Q^{\prime}$ and $Q$ the radiation emitted will arrive at the line QP at time $t$. Hence QP forms the wavefront of all radiation emitted prior to $t$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_6a2dacf5647d8430e732g-602.jpg?height=302&width=457&top_left_y=1199&top_left_x=443)

Fig. $5.13$

(b) As $|\cos \theta| \leq 1$, we require $\beta \geq \frac{1}{n}$ for emission of erenkov radiation. Hence we require

$$
\gamma=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\beta^{2}}} \geq\left(1-\frac{1}{n^{2}}\right)^{-\frac{1}{2}}=\frac{n}{\sqrt{n^{2}-1}} .
$$



\section{Thus the particle must have a kinetic energy greater than}

$$
\begin{aligned}
T &=(\gamma-1) m_{0} c^{2} \\
&=\left[\frac{n}{\sqrt{(n+1)(n-1)}}-1\right] m_{0} c^{2} \\
& \approx\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \times 1.35 \times 10^{-4}}}-1\right) \times 0.5 \\
& \approx 29.93 \mathrm{MeV} .
\end{aligned}
$$

(c) For a relativistic particle of momentum $P \gg m_{0} c$,

$$
\gamma=\frac{E}{m_{0} c^{2}}=\frac{\sqrt{P^{2} c^{2}+m_{0}^{2} c^{4}}}{m_{0} c^{2}} \approx \frac{P}{m_{0} c} .
$$

With $P$ fixed we have

$$
d \gamma=-\frac{P}{c} \cdot \frac{d m_{0}}{m_{0}^{2}} .
$$

Now $\beta=\frac{\gamma \beta}{\gamma}=\sqrt{\frac{\gamma^{2}-1}{\gamma^{2}}}=\sqrt{1-\frac{1}{\gamma^{2}}} \approx 1-\frac{1}{2 \gamma^{2}}$ for $\gamma \gg 1$, so that

$$
d \beta=\frac{d \gamma}{\gamma^{3}} .
$$

For the erenkov radiation emitted by the particle, we have

$$
\cos \theta=\frac{1}{\beta n},
$$

or

$$
d \beta=n \beta^{2} \sin \theta d \theta .
$$

Combining the above we have

$$
\left|\frac{d m_{0}}{m_{0}}\right|=\frac{m_{0} c}{P} d \gamma \approx \frac{d \gamma}{\gamma}=\gamma^{2} \beta=n \beta^{2} \gamma^{2} \sin \theta d \theta=\beta \gamma^{2} \tan \theta d \theta .
$$

With $\gamma=\frac{P c}{m_{0} c^{2}}=\frac{100}{1}=100, n=1+1.35 \times 10^{-4}$, we have

$$
\beta \approx 1-\frac{1}{2 \times 10^{4}}=1-5 \times 10^{-5},
$$

$\cos \theta=\frac{1}{\beta n}=\left(1-5 \times 10^{-5}\right)^{-1}\left(1+1.35 \times 10^{-4}\right)^{-1} \approx 1-8.5 \times 10^{-5}$, 

$$
\begin{aligned}
\tan \theta=\sqrt{\frac{1}{\cos ^{2} \theta}-1} &=\sqrt{\left(1-8.5 \times 10^{-5}\right)^{-2}-1} \\
& \approx \sqrt{1.7 \times 10^{-4}} \approx 1.3 \times 10^{-2},
\end{aligned}
$$

and hence

$$
\left|\frac{d m_{0}}{m_{0}}\right|=\left(1-5 \times 10^{-5}\right) \times 10^{4} \times 1.3 \times 10^{-2} \times 10^{-3}=0.13
$$

\section{3}

A waveguide is formed by two infinite parallel perfectly conducting planes separated by a distance $a$. The gap between the planes is filled with a gas whose index of refraction is $n$. (This is taken to be frequency independent.)
