\mathbf{D}=\varepsilon \mathbf{E}^{\prime}=\varepsilon_{0} \mathbf{E}^{\prime}+\mathbf{P} .
$$

Hence the effective dielectric constant of the plasma is given by

$$
\varepsilon=\varepsilon_{0}+\frac{P}{E^{\prime}}=\varepsilon_{0}-\frac{n_{0} e^{2}}{m \omega^{2}},
$$

or

$$
\frac{\varepsilon}{\varepsilon_{0}}=1-\left(\frac{\omega_{p}}{\omega}\right)^{2}
$$

where

$$
\omega_{p}=\sqrt{\frac{n_{0} e^{2}}{\varepsilon_{0} m}}
$$

is called the plasma (angular) frequency.

The index of refraction of the plasma is therefore

$$
n=\sqrt{\frac{\mu_{0} \varepsilon}{\mu_{0} \varepsilon_{0}}}=\sqrt{\frac{\varepsilon}{\varepsilon_{0}}}=\sqrt{1-\left(\frac{\omega_{\mathrm{p}}}{\omega}\right)^{2}} .
$$

(c) Consider the primary wave $\mathbf{E}_{0}=E_{0} e^{i(k z-\omega t)} \mathbf{e}_{x}$, where $k=\frac{\omega}{c}$, as incident normally on the boundary of the plasma, then the wave inside the plasma is also a plane polarized wave, with amplitude $E_{0}^{\prime}=\frac{2 E_{0}}{1+n}$ and wave number $k^{\prime}=\frac{\omega}{c} n=k n$ (see Problem 4011). Hence the electric intensity of the wave in the region of the edge of the plasma is

$$
\mathbf{E}^{\prime}=\frac{2 E_{0}}{1+n} e^{i(k n z-\omega t)} \mathbf{e}_{z}
$$



\section{Note that for $\omega>\omega_{p}, n$ and $k n$ are real and $\mathbf{E}^{\prime}$ propagates as wave, but for $\omega<\omega_{p}, n$ and $k n$ are imaginary and $\boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{\prime}$ attenuates exponentially as shown in Fig. $5.24$.}

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_6a2dacf5647d8430e732g-651.jpg?height=283&width=376&top_left_y=327&top_left_x=490)

Fig. $5.24$

\section{5}

A "tenuous plasma" consists of free electric charges of mass $m$ and charge $e$. There are $n$ charges per unit volume. Assume that the density is uniform and that interactions between the charges may be neglected. Electromagnetic plane waves (frequency $\omega$, wave number $k$ ) are incident on the plasma.

\section{(a) Find the conductivity $\sigma$ as a function of $\omega$. \\ (b) Find the dispersion relation, i.e., find the relation between $k$ and $\omega$. \\ (c) Find the index of refraction as a function of $\omega$. The plasma fre- quency is defined by}

$$
\omega_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}=\frac{4 \pi n e^{2}}{m},
$$

if $e$ is expressed in e.s.u. units. What happens if $\omega<\omega_{p}$ ?

(d) Now suppose there is an external magnetic field $\mathbf{B}_{0}$. Consider plane waves traveling parallel to $B_{0}$. Show that the index of refraction is different for right and left circularly polarized waves. (Assume that B of the traveling wave is negligible compared with $\mathbf{B}_{0}$.)

(Princeton)

\section{Solution:}

Gaussian units are to be used for this problem.

The electric vector of the incident wave at a charge is $\mathcal{\Sigma}_{0} e^{-i \omega t}$, while the effect of the magnetic vector can be ignored in the non-relativistic case. Thus the equation of motion for a charge $e$ in the plasma is

$$
m \ddot{x}=e \mathbb{E}_{0} e^{-i \omega t} .
$$



\section{In the steady state $x=x_{0} e^{-i \omega t}$. Substitution gives}

$$
\mathrm{x}_{0}=-\frac{e \mathrm{\Sigma}_{0}}{m \omega^{2}},
$$

or

$$
x=-\frac{e \bar{\Sigma}}{m \omega^{2}} .
$$

(a) The motion of the charges gives rise to a current density

$$
\mathbf{j}=n e \dot{\mathrm{x}}=i \frac{n e^{2}}{m \omega} \mathbf{E}
$$

so that the conductivity is

$$
\sigma=\frac{j}{E}=i \frac{n e^{2}}{m \omega} .
$$

(b) The polarization of the plasma is

$$
\mathbf{P}=n e x=-\frac{n e^{2}}{m \omega^{2}} \mathbf{E}=\chi_{\mathrm{e}} \mathbf{E}
$$

where $\chi_{\mathrm{e}}$ is the polarizability of the plasma. The dielectric constant is by definition

$$
\varepsilon=1+4 \pi \chi_{\mathrm{e}}=1-\frac{4 \pi n e^{2}}{m \omega^{2}}=1-\frac{\omega_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}}{\omega^{2}},
$$

where

$$
\omega_{\mathrm{p}}=\sqrt{\frac{4 \pi n e^{2}}{m}}
$$

is the plasma frequency. Then the refractive index of the plasma is

$$
n=\sqrt{\varepsilon}=\sqrt{1-\frac{\omega_{p}^{2}}{\omega^{2}}},
$$

as we may assume $\mu=\mu_{0}=1$ for the plasma. The wave number in the plasma is therefore given by

$$
k^{2}=\frac{\omega^{2} n^{2}}{c^{2}}=\frac{1}{c^{2}}\left(\omega^{2}-\omega_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}\right),
$$

which is the dispersion relation. (c) The index of refraction is

$$
n=\sqrt{\varepsilon \mu}=\sqrt{\varepsilon}=\left(1-\frac{\omega_{p}^{2}}{\omega^{2}}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}
$$

If $\omega<\omega_{p}, n$ is an imaginary number, and so is $k$. Take the $z$-axis along the direction of propagation. Writing $k=i \kappa$, where $\kappa$ is real, we see that $e^{i k z}=e^{-\kappa z}$, so the wave will attenuate exponentially and there is no propagation, the plasma serving only to reflect the incident wave.

(d) As $\mathbf{B}=B_{0} \mathbf{e}_{z}, k=k \mathbf{e}_{z}$, the equation of motion for a charge $e$ in the plasma is

$$
m \ddot{\mathbf{x}}=e \mathbf{E}+\frac{e}{c} \mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{B}_{0} \text {. }
$$

Since the plane wave is transverse, we have $\mathrm{E}=E_{x} \mathbf{e}_{x}+E_{y} \mathbf{e}_{y}$. In the steady state, the charge will oscillate with the same frequency $\omega$ and the solution will have the form $x=x_{0} e^{-i \omega t}$. Thus $v=\dot{x}=(-i \omega) x$, and the component equations are

$$
\begin{aligned}
m \ddot{x} &=e E_{x}+\frac{e}{c} \dot{y} B_{0}, \\
m \ddot{y} &=e E_{y}-\frac{e}{c} \dot{x} B_{0}, \\
m \ddot{z} &=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Suppose $z$ and $\dot{z}$ are both zero initially. Then $z=0$ and $x=x e_{x}+y e_{y}$.

For the right circularly polarized wave (looking against the direction of propagation $E$ rotates to the right, i.e., clockwise) the electric vector is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{E}_{\mathbf{R}} &=\operatorname{Re}\left\{E_{0}\left(\mathbf{e}_{x}+e^{-i \frac{\pi}{2}} \mathbf{e}_{y}\right) e^{-i \omega t}\right\} \\
&=E_{0} \cos (\omega t) e_{x}-E_{0} \sin (\omega t) \mathbf{e}_{y}
\end{aligned}
$$

and Eqs. (1) and (2) reduce to

$$
\begin{aligned}
m \ddot{x} &=e E_{0} \cos \omega t+\frac{e}{c} B_{0} \dot{y}, \\
m \ddot{y} &=-e E_{0} \sin \omega t-\frac{e}{c} B_{0} \dot{x}
\end{aligned}
$$

Let $u=x-i y, \omega_{c}=\frac{e B_{0}}{m c}$, the above equations can be combined into

$$
\ddot{u}-i \omega_{c} \dot{u}=\frac{e E_{0}}{m}(\cos \omega t+i \sin \omega t)=\frac{e E_{0}}{m} e^{i \omega t}
$$



\section{The steady state solution is}

$$
u=u_{0} e^{i \omega t}
$$

\section{Substitution gives}

$$
u_{0}=-\frac{e E_{0}}{m \omega\left(\omega-\omega_{c}\right)}
$$

hence

$$
u=-\frac{e E_{0}(\cos \omega t+i \sin \omega t)}{m \omega\left(\omega-\omega_{c}\right)},
$$

whose real and imaginary parts respectively give

$$
x=-\frac{e E_{0} \cos \omega t}{m \omega\left(\omega-\omega_{c}\right)}, \quad y=\frac{e E_{0} \sin \omega t}{m \omega\left(\omega-\omega_{c}\right)}
$$

or, in vector form,

$$
x=-\frac{e \mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{R}}}{m \omega\left(\omega-\omega_{c}\right)} .
$$

Thus for the right circularly polarized wave, the polarizability of the plasma is

$$
\chi_{\mathrm{eR}}=-\frac{n e^{2}}{m \omega\left(\omega-\omega_{c}\right)},
$$

and the corresponding index of refraction is

$$
\begin{aligned}
n_{\mathrm{R}} &=\sqrt{\varepsilon_{\mathbf{R}}}=\sqrt{1+4 \pi \chi_{\mathrm{e}}} \\
&=\left(1-\frac{4 \pi n e^{2}}{m \omega\left(\omega-\omega_{\mathrm{c}}\right)}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}},
\end{aligned}
$$

or, in terms of the plasma frequency $\omega_{p}$,

$$
n_{R}=\left[1-\frac{\omega_{p}^{2}}{\omega\left(\omega-\omega_{c}\right)}\right]^{\frac{1}{2}} \text {. }
$$

For the left circularly polarized wave, the electric vector is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{E}_{\mathbf{L}} &=\operatorname{Re}\left\{E_{0}\left(\mathbf{e}_{x}+e^{i \frac{\pi}{2}} \mathbf{e}_{y}\right) e^{-i \omega t}\right\} \\
&=E_{0} \cos (\omega t) \mathbf{e}_{x}+E_{0} \sin (\omega t) \mathbf{e}_{y} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Then, putting $u=x+i y$ and repeating the above procedure, we obtain the index of refraction

$$
n_{L}=\left[1-\frac{\omega_{p}^{2}}{\omega\left(\omega+\omega_{c}\right)}\right]^{\frac{1}{2}} \text {. }
$$

It is obvious that $n_{L} \neq n_{R}$, unless $\omega_{c}=0$, i.e., $B_{0}=0$.

\section{6} by

The dispersion relation for electromagnetic waves in a plasma is given

$$
\omega^{2}(k)=\omega_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}+c^{2} k^{2},
$$

where the plasma frequency $\omega_{p}$ is defined as

$$
\omega_{p}^{2}=\frac{4 \pi N e^{2}}{m}
$$

for an electron density $N$, charge per electron $e$, and mass per electron $m$.

(a) For $\omega>\omega_{p}$, find the index of refraction $n$ of the plasma.

(b) For $\omega>\omega_{p}$, is $n$ greater than or less than 1? Discuss.

(c) For $\omega>\omega_{p}$, calculate the velocity at which messages can be transmitted through the plasma.

(d) For $\omega<\omega_{p}$, describe quantitatively the behavior of an electromagnetic wave in the plasma.

$(U C$, Berkeley $)$

\section{Solution:}
(a) $n=\left(1-\omega_{p}^{2} / \omega^{2}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}$.
(b) For $\omega>\omega_{p}, n<1$.
(c) For $\omega>\omega_{p}$, the phase velocity in the plasma is

$$
v_{p}=\frac{c}{n}>c .
$$

However, messages or signals are transmitted with the group velocity

$$
v_{\mathrm{g}}=\frac{d \omega}{d k}=\frac{c^{2} k}{\omega}=c\left(1-\omega_{\mathrm{p}}^{2} / \omega^{2}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}} .
$$

As $\omega>\omega_{p}$, it is clear that $v_{g}<c$. (d) For $\omega<\omega_{p}, n$ and $k$ are imaginary and the electromagnetic waves attenuate exponentially after entering into the plasma. Hence electromagnetic waves of frequencies $\omega<\omega_{p}$ cannot propagate in the plasma.

\section{7}

Discuss the propagation of electromagnetic waves of frequency $\omega$ through a region filled with free electric charges (mass $m$ and charge $e$ ) of density $N$ per $\mathrm{cm}^{3}$.

(a) In particular, find an expression for the index of refraction and show that under certain conditions it may be complex.

(b) Discuss the reflection and transmission of waves at normal incidence under conditions when the index of refraction is real, and when it is complex.

(c) Show that there is a critical frequency (the plasma frequency) dividing the real and complex regions of behavior.

(d) Verify that the critical frequency lies in the radio range $\left(N=10^{6}\right)$ for the ionosphere and in the ultraviolet for metallic sodium $(N=2.5 \times$ $\left.10^{22}\right)$

(UC, Berkeley)

\section{Solution:}

(a) See Problem 5044.

(b) For normal incidence, if the index of refraction is real, both reflection and transmission will take place. Let the amplitude of the incident wave be $E_{0}$, then the amplitude of the reflected wave and the reflectivity are respectively (Problem 4011)

$$
E_{0}^{\prime}=\frac{1-n}{1+n} E_{0}, \quad R=\left(\frac{1-n}{1+n}\right)^{2}
$$

and the amplitude of the transmitted wave and the transmittivity are respectively

$$
E_{0}^{\prime \prime}=\frac{2}{1+n} E_{0}, \quad T=\frac{4 n}{(1+n)^{2}} .
$$

If $n$ is complex, the transmitted wave will attenuate exponentially so that effectively only reflection occurs (see Problem 5044 ). (c) The index of refraction is $n=\left(1-\frac{\omega_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}}{\omega^{2}}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}$, where $\omega_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}=\frac{N e^{2}}{m \varepsilon_{0}}$ in SI units and $\omega_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}=\frac{4 \pi N e^{2}}{m}$ in Gaussian units. $n$ is real for $\omega>\omega_{\mathrm{p}}$ and imaginary for $\omega<\omega_{p}$. Thus $\omega_{p}$ can be considered a critical frequency.

(d) For the electron

$$
e=1.6 \times 10^{-19} \mathrm{C}, \quad m=9.1 \times 10^{-31} \mathrm{~kg} .
$$

With $N=10^{6} / \mathrm{cm}^{3}$ for the ionosphere and $\varepsilon_{0}=8.85 \times 10^{-12} \mathrm{~F} / \mathrm{m}$, they give

$$
\omega_{\mathrm{p}}=\sqrt{\frac{N e^{2}}{m \varepsilon_{0}}}=\left(\frac{10^{6} \times 10^{6} \times\left(1.6 \times 10^{-19}\right)^{2}}{9.1 \times 10^{-31} \times 8.85 \times 10^{-12}}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}=5.64 \times 10^{7} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}
$$

within the range of radio frequencies.

For metallic sodium, $N=2.5 \times 10^{22} / \mathrm{cm}^{3}$, so that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\omega_{p} &=\left(\frac{2.5 \times 10^{22} \times 10^{6} \times\left(1.6 \times 10^{-19}\right)^{2}}{9.1 \times 10^{-31} \times 8.85 \times 10^{-12}}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}} \\
&=8.91 \times 10^{15} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}
\end{aligned}
$$

in the ultraviolet range.

5048

Assume that the ionosphere consists of a uniform plasma of free electrons and neglect collisions.

(a) Derive an expression for the index of refraction for electromagnetic waves propagating in this medium in terms of the frequency.

(b) Now suppose that there is an external uniform static magnetic field due to the earth, parallel to the direction of propagation of the electromagnetic waves. In this case, left and right circularly polarized waves will have different indices of refraction; derive the expressions for both of them.

(c) There is a certain frequency below which the electromagnetic wave incident on the plasma is completely reflected. Calculate this frequency for both left and right polarized waves, given that the density of electrons is $10^{5} \mathrm{~cm}^{-3}$ and $B=0.3$ gauss. 

\section{Solution:}

(a), (b) See Problem 5045.

(c) The refractive index $n$ of the plasma is given by

$$
n^{2}=1-\frac{\omega_{p}^{2}}{\omega^{2}},
$$

where $\omega_{\mathrm{p}}=\sqrt{\frac{4 \pi N e^{2}}{m}}$ is the plasma frequency, $N$ being the density of free electrons. When $n^{2}<0, n$ is imaginary and electromagnetic waves of (angular) frequency $\omega$ cannot propagate in the plasma. Hence the cutoff frequency is that for which $n=0$, i.e., $\omega_{p}$.

For frequencies $<\omega_{p}$, the wave will be totally reflected by the plasma. For the right and left circularly polarized waves, the refractive indices $n_{R}$ and $n_{L}$ are given by (Problem 5045)

$$
n_{\mp}^{2}=1-\frac{\omega_{p}^{2}}{\omega\left(\omega \mp \omega_{c}\right)},
$$

where $n_{-}=n_{R}, \omega_{c}=\frac{e B}{m c}$. The cutoff frequencies are given by $n_{\mp}^{2}=0$. Thus the cutoff frequencies for right and left circularly polarized waves are respectively

$$
\omega_{\mathrm{Rc}}=\frac{\omega_{\mathrm{c}}+\sqrt{\omega_{\mathrm{c}}^{2}+4 \omega_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}}}{2}, \quad \omega_{\mathrm{Lc}}=\frac{-\omega_{\mathrm{c}}+\sqrt{\omega_{\mathrm{c}}^{2}+4 \omega_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}}}{2} .
$$

With $N=10^{5} / \mathrm{cm}^{3}, B=0.3 \mathrm{Gs}$, and $m=9.1 \times 10^{-28} \mathrm{~g}, e=4.8 \times 10^{-10}$ e.s.u. for the electron, we have

$$
\begin{gathered}
\omega_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}=\frac{4 \pi \times 10^{5} \times\left(4.8 \times 10^{-10}\right)}{9.1 \times 10^{-28}}=3.18 \times 10^{14} \mathrm{~s}^{-2}, \\
\omega_{\mathrm{c}}=\frac{4.8 \times 10^{-10} \times 0.3}{3 \times 10^{10} \times 9.1 \times 10^{-28}}=5.27 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}
\end{gathered}
$$

and hence

$$
\omega_{\mathrm{Rc}}=2.1 \times 10^{7} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}, \quad \omega_{\mathrm{Lc}}=1.5 \times 10^{7} \mathrm{~s}^{-1} .
$$

5049

Derive an expression for the penetration depth of a very low frequency electromagnetic wave into a plasma in which electrons are free to move. Express your answer in terms of the electron density $n_{0}$, electron charge $e$ and mass $m$. What does "very low" mean in this context? What is the depth in $\mathrm{cm}$ for $n_{0}=10^{14} \mathrm{~cm}^{-3}$ ?

$(U C$, Berkeley)

\section{Solution:}

The dispersion relation for a plasma is (Problem 5045)

$$
k^{2}=\frac{\omega^{2}}{c^{2}}\left(1-\frac{\omega_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}}{\omega^{2}}\right),
$$

where $\omega_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}=\frac{n_{0} e^{2}}{m \varepsilon_{0}}$ is the plasma frequency. A "very low" frequency means that the frequency satisfies $\omega \ll \omega_{p}$. For such frequencies $k$ is imaginary. Let $k=i \kappa$, where $\kappa=\frac{1}{c} \sqrt{\omega_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}-\omega_{\mathrm{c}}^{2}}$, then $e^{i k z}=e^{-\kappa z}$, the $z$-axis being taken along the direction of propagation. This means the wave amplitude attenuates exponentially in the plasma. The penetration depth $\delta$ is defined as the depth from the plasma surface where the amplitude is $e^{-1}$ of its surface value, i.e.,

$$
\kappa \delta=1,
$$

or

$$
\delta=\frac{1}{\kappa}=\frac{c}{\sqrt{\omega_{p}^{2}-\omega^{2}}} \approx \frac{1}{\omega_{p}} .
$$

With $n_{0}=10^{14} \mathrm{~cm}^{-3}$, we have

$$
\omega_{p}=\left(\frac{10^{14} \times 10^{6} \times\left(1.6 \times 10^{-19}\right)^{2}}{9.1 \times 10^{-31} \times 8.85 \times 10^{-12}}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}} \approx 5.64 \times 10^{11} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}
$$

and

$$
\delta=\frac{3 \times 10^{10}}{5.64 \times 10^{11}}=0.053 \mathrm{~cm}
$$

\section{0}

In the presence of a uniform static magnetic field $\mathbf{H}$, a medium may become magnetized. The magnetization may be coupled self-consistently to an electromagnetic field set up in the medium.

(a) Write down an equation of motion governing the time variation of the magnetization under the influence of a (generally time-dependent) magnetic field. (b) An electromagnetic field is, of course, in turn generated by the time-dependent magnetization as described by the appropriate Maxwell's equations. Assume the dielectric constant $\varepsilon=1$ for the magnetic medium. Find the dispersion relation $\omega=\omega(k)$ for the propagation of a plane wave of magnetization in the medium.

$(S U N Y, B u f f a l o)$

\section{Solution:}

(a) Assuming the medium to be linear, $M=\chi_{m} \mathbf{H}$, we have, by the definition of permeability $\mu$

$$
\mathbf{M}(t)=\chi_{m}(\omega) \mathbf{H}(t)=\frac{\mu(\omega)-1}{4 \pi} \mathbf{H}(t) .
$$

(b) Maxwell's equations for the medium are

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\nabla \cdot \mathbf{D}=4 \pi \rho, & \nabla \cdot \mathbf{B}=0, \\
\nabla \times \mathbf{E}=-\frac{1}{c} \frac{\partial \mathbf{B}}{\partial t}, & \nabla \times \mathbf{H}=\frac{4 \pi}{c} \mathbf{j}+\frac{1}{c} \frac{\partial \mathbf{D}}{\partial t} .
\end{array}
$$

Note that $B$ in the equations is the superposition of the external field and the time-dependent field produced by the magnetization $M(t)$.

Consider the medium as isolated and uncharged, then $\rho=\mathbf{j}=0$. Also $\mathbf{D}=\mathbf{E}$ as $\varepsilon=1$. Maxwell's equations now reduce to

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\nabla \cdot \mathbf{E}=0, & \nabla \cdot \mathbf{B}=0, \\
\nabla \times \mathbf{E}=-\frac{1}{c} \frac{\partial \mathbf{B}}{\partial t}, & \nabla \times \mathbf{H}=\frac{1}{c} \frac{\partial \mathbf{E}}{\partial t},
\end{array}
$$

with

$$
\mathbf{B}=\boldsymbol{\mu} \mathbf{H} .
$$

Deduce from these equations the wave equation

$$
\nabla^{2} \mathbf{H}-\frac{\mu}{c^{2}} \frac{\partial^{2} \mathrm{H}}{\partial t^{2}}=0 .
$$

Consider a plane wave solution

$$
\mathbf{H}(t)=\mathbf{H}_{0} e^{i(\mathbf{k} \cdot \mathbf{r}-\omega t)} .
$$

Substitution in the wave equation gives the dispersion relation

$$
k^{2}-\mu \frac{\omega^{2}}{c^{2}}=0,
$$

or

$$
k=\frac{\omega}{v}=\frac{\omega}{c} \sqrt{\mu(\omega)} \text {. }
$$

The magnetization $M$ can then be represented by a plane wave

$$
M(t)=\chi_{m}(\omega) \mathbf{H}(t)=\chi_{m} \mathbf{H}_{0} e^{i(k \cdot r-\omega t)} .
$$

As $M$ satisfies the same wave equation the dispersion relation above remains valid.

\section{1}

In a classical theory of the dispersion of light in a transparent dielectric medium one can assume that the light wave interacts with atomic electrons which are bound in harmonic oscillator potentials. In the simplest case, the medium contains $N$ electrons per unit volume with the same resonance frequency $\omega_{0}$.

(a) Calculate the response of one such electron to a linearly polarized electromagnetic plane wave of electric field amplitude $E_{0}$ and frequency $\omega$.

(b) For the medium, give expressions for the atomic polarizability, the dielectric susceptibility and the refractive index as functions of the light frequency. What happens near resonance? What happens above resonance? The phase velocity of the light wave exceeds the vacuum velocity of light if the refractive index becomes smaller than 1. Does this violate the principles of the special theory of relativity?

$(S U N Y, B u f f a l 0)$

\section{Solution:}

(a) The equation of motion for the electron is

$$
m \ddot{\mathbf{x}}=-m \omega_{0}^{2} \mathbf{x}-e \mathbf{E}_{0} e^{-i \omega t} .
$$

Consider the steady state solution $x=x_{0} e^{-i \omega t}$. Substituting in the equation gives

$$
\mathbf{x}=\frac{e \mathbf{E}_{0}}{m\left(\omega^{2}-\omega_{0}^{2}\right)} e^{-i \omega t} .
$$

(b) Assume that each atom contributes only one oscillating electron. The electric dipole moment of the atom in the field of the light wave is

$$
\mathbf{p}=-e \mathbf{x}=-\frac{e^{2} \mathbf{E}}{m\left(\omega^{2}-\omega_{0}^{2}\right)},
$$



\section{giving the atomic polarizability}

$$
\alpha=\frac{p}{E}=\frac{e^{2}}{m\left(\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}\right)}
$$

As there are $N$ electrons per unit volume, the polarization of the medium is

$$
\mathbf{P}=n p=\frac{N e^{2} \mathbf{E}}{m\left(\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}\right)} .
$$

The electric displacement is by definition

$$
\mathbf{D}=\varepsilon \mathbf{E}=\varepsilon_{0} \mathbf{E}+\mathbf{P} \text {. }
$$

Hence the dielectric constant is

$$
\varepsilon=\varepsilon_{0}+\frac{N e^{2}}{m\left(\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}\right)} .
$$

Assume the medium to be non-ferromagnetic, then $\mu=\mu_{0}$, and the refractive index is given by

$$
n=\sqrt{\frac{\mu \varepsilon}{\mu_{0} \varepsilon_{0}}}=\sqrt{\frac{\varepsilon}{\varepsilon_{0}}} .
$$

\section{Putting}

$$
\omega_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}=\frac{N e^{2}}{m \varepsilon_{0}},
$$

we have

$$
n=\left(1+\frac{\omega_{p}^{2}}{\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}} \text {. }
$$

For $\omega<\omega_{0}$, we have $\varepsilon>\varepsilon_{0}, n>1$, and the phase velocity of the wave in the medium is $v_{\mathrm{p}}=\frac{c}{n}<c$.

For $\omega_{0}<\omega<\sqrt{\omega_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}+\omega_{0}^{2}}, n$ is real but smaller than unity. This means that $v_{p}>c$ and the wave propagates with a velocity greater than the velocity of light in free space. However, the energy or signal carried by the wave travels with the group velocity $v_{g}$ given by

$$
\frac{1}{v_{\mathrm{g}}}=\frac{d k}{d \omega}=\frac{n}{c}+\frac{\omega}{c} \frac{d n}{d \omega}
$$

as $k=\frac{\omega n}{c}$. Equation (1) gives

$$
\frac{1}{v_{\mathrm{g}}}=\frac{1}{c n}\left(\frac{\omega^{2}-n^{2} \omega_{0}^{2}}{\omega^{2}-\omega_{0}^{2}}\right)>\frac{1}{c n}=\frac{v_{\mathrm{p}}}{c^{2}}
$$

as $n>1$. Then as $v_{\mathrm{p}}>c, v_{\mathrm{g}}<c$. Hence there is no violation of the principles of special relativity. For both the above cases, $\boldsymbol{n}$ increases with increasing $\omega$ and the dispersion is said to be normal.

For $\omega \approx \omega_{0}$, Eq. (1) does not hold but damping (collision and radiation) must be taken into account. Equation (1) is modified to

$$
\begin{aligned}
n & \approx\left[1+\frac{\omega_{p}^{2}\left(\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}\right)}{\left(\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}\right)^{2}+\omega^{2} \gamma^{2}}\right]^{\frac{1}{2}} \\
& \approx 1+\frac{\omega_{p}^{2}\left(\omega_{0}-\omega\right)}{\gamma^{2} \omega_{0}} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus $n \approx 1$ for $\omega=\omega_{0}$. As $\omega$ increases from a value smaller than $\omega_{0}$ to one larger than $\omega_{0}, n$ decreases from a value greater than unity to one smaller than unity. In this region $n$ decreases with increasing $\omega$ and the dispersion is said to be anomalous.

For $\omega>\sqrt{\omega_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}+\omega_{0}^{2}}, n$ is imaginary so that $k=\frac{\omega}{c} n$ is also imaginary. Let it be $i \kappa$. Then the wave amplitude at a point distance $r$ from the surface of the medium simply attenuates according to $e^{-\kappa r}$ and propagation is not possible in the medium.

Near resonance $\omega \approx \omega_{0}$, the absorption coefficient becomes very large. Thus the medium is essentially opaque to the wave at $\omega \approx \omega_{0}$ and for $\omega>\sqrt{\omega_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}+\omega_{0}^{2}}$

\section{2}

Consider a model of an isotropic medium composed of $N$ harmonically bound particles of charge $e$, mass $m$ and natural frequency $\omega_{0}$, per unit volume.

(a) Show that, for a zero magnetic field, the dielectric function of the medium is given by

$$
\varepsilon(\omega)=1+\frac{4 \pi N e^{2} / m}{\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}} .
$$

(b) (The Faraday effect) Now a static magnetic field $B$ in the direction of propagation of the electromagnetic wave is added. Show that the left and right circularly polarized electromagnetic waves have different dielectric functions, with the difference equals to

$$
\delta \varepsilon(\omega)=\frac{4 \pi N e^{2}}{m} \frac{2 e B \omega / m c}{\left(\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}\right)^{2}-(e B \omega / m c)^{2}} .
$$

(Chicago)

Solution:

(a) See Problem 5051.

(b) Take the $z$-axis along the direction of propagation, then $k=k \mathbf{e}_{z}$. When a static magnetic field $\mathbf{B}=B \mathbf{e}_{z}$ is added, the equation of motion for a harmonically bounded particle is

$$
m \ddot{\mathrm{x}}=-m \omega_{0}^{2} \mathrm{x}+e \mathbf{E}+\frac{e}{c} \dot{\mathrm{x}} \times \mathbf{B} .
$$

As plane electromagnetic waves are transverse, $\mathbf{E}$ has only $x$ and $y$ components. The component equations are

$$
\begin{aligned}
m \ddot{x} &=-m \omega_{0}^{2} x+e E_{x}+\frac{e}{c} B \dot{y}, \\
m \ddot{y} &=-m \omega_{0}^{2} y+e E_{y}-\frac{e}{c} B \dot{x}, \\
m \ddot{z} &=-m \omega_{0}^{2} z
\end{aligned}
$$

The last equation shows that motion along the $z$ direction is harmonic but not affected by the applied fields and can thus be neglected. For the right circularly polarized wave (Problem 5045)

$$
\mathbf{E}_{R}=E_{0} \cos (\omega t) \mathbf{e}_{x}-E_{0} \sin (\omega t) \mathbf{e}_{y}
$$

so the remaining equations of motion are

Putting

$$
\begin{aligned}
&m \ddot{x}=-m \omega_{0}^{2} x+e E_{0} \cos \omega t+\frac{e}{c} B \dot{y}, \\
&m \ddot{y}=-m \omega_{0}^{2} y-e E_{0} \sin \omega t-\frac{e}{c} B \dot{x}
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
u=x+i y, \quad \omega_{c}=\frac{e B}{m c},
$$

$(1)-i \times(2)$ gives

$$
\ddot{u}-i \omega_{c} \dot{u}+\omega_{0}^{2} u=\frac{e E_{0}}{m}(\cos \omega t+i \sin \omega t)=\frac{e E_{0}}{m} e^{i \omega t} .
$$

In the steady state, $u \sim e^{i \omega t}$. Substitution in the above gives

$$
u=\frac{e E_{0}(\cos \omega t+i \sin \omega t)}{m\left(\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}+\omega \omega_{c}\right)} .
$$

Separating the real and imaginary parts we have

$$
x=\frac{e E_{0} \cos \omega t}{m\left(\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}+\omega \omega_{c}\right)}, \quad y=-\frac{e E_{0} \sin \omega t}{m\left(\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}+\omega \omega_{c}\right)} .
$$

Combining the above in vector form gives

$$
x=\frac{e \mathbf{E}_{\mathbf{R}}}{m\left(\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}+\omega \omega_{c}\right)} .
$$

Hence the polarization of the medium due to the right circularly polarized wave is

$$
\mathbf{P}=N e x=\frac{N e^{2} \mathbf{E}_{\mathbf{R}}}{m\left(\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}+\omega \omega_{c}\right)} .
$$

As $\varepsilon=1+4 \pi \frac{P}{E}$, the above gives

$$
\varepsilon_{\mathbf{R}}=1+\frac{4 \pi N e^{2}}{m\left(\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}+\omega \omega_{c}\right)} .
$$

Similarly for the left circularly polarized wave

$$
\mathbf{E}_{L}=E_{0} \cos (\omega t) \mathbf{e}_{x}+E_{0} \sin (\omega t) \mathbf{e}_{y}
$$

we find

$$
\varepsilon_{\mathrm{L}}=1+\frac{4 \pi N e^{2}}{m\left(\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}-\omega \omega_{c}\right)} .
$$

The difference between $\varepsilon_{L}$ and $\varepsilon_{R}$ is therefore

$$
\begin{aligned}
\delta \varepsilon(\omega) &=\varepsilon_{\mathrm{L}}-\varepsilon_{\mathbf{R}} \\
&=\frac{4 \pi N e^{2}}{m}\left[\frac{1}{\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}-\omega \omega_{\mathrm{c}}}-\frac{1}{\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}+\omega \omega_{\mathrm{c}}}\right] \\
&=\frac{4 \pi N e^{2}}{m} \cdot \frac{2 e B \omega / m c}{\left(\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}\right)^{2}-(e B \omega / m c)^{2}} .
\end{aligned}
$$



\section{3}

An electrically neutral collisionless plasma of uniform density $n_{0}$ is at rest and is permeated by a uniform magnetic field $\left(0,0, B_{0}\right)$. Consider an electromagnetic wave of frequency $\omega$ propagating parallel to the magnetic field. Show that the wave splits into two waves for which the refractive indices are

$$
n_{R}^{2}=1-\frac{\omega_{p}^{2} / \omega^{2}}{1-\left(\omega_{c} / \omega\right)}, \quad n_{L}^{2}=1-\frac{\omega_{p}^{2} / \omega^{2}}{1+\left(\omega_{c} / \omega\right)}
$$

where the plasma frequency is $\omega_{\mathrm{p}}=\left(4 \pi n_{0} e^{2} / m_{\mathrm{e}}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}$ and the cyclotron frequency is $\omega_{\mathrm{c}}=e B_{0} / m_{\mathrm{e}} c$. Show that these waves are, respectively, righthand and left-hand circularly polarized. Explain physically why the refractive index can be less than one. What happens when it vanishes? What happens when it becomes infinite? (You may assume that only the electrons respond to the wave and that the positive charges remain uniformly distributed.)

$(U C$, Berkeley)

\section{Solution:}

Suppose the neutral plasma consists of free electrons and an equal number of positive charges. Only the free electrons, for which $\omega_{0}=0$, take part significantly in the oscillations. Using the results of problem 5045 we have, as $\mu \approx \mu_{0}=1$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
&n_{\mathrm{R}}^{2}=\varepsilon_{\mathrm{R}}=1-\frac{4 \pi n_{0} e^{2}}{m_{\mathrm{e}} \omega^{2}\left(1-\omega_{\mathrm{c}} / \omega\right)}=1-\frac{\omega_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}}{\omega\left(\omega-\omega_{\mathrm{c}}\right)}, \\
&n_{\mathrm{L}}^{2}=\varepsilon_{\mathrm{L}}=1-\frac{4 \pi n_{0} e^{2}}{m_{\mathrm{e}} \omega^{2}\left(1+\omega_{\mathrm{c}} / \omega\right)}=1-\frac{\omega_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}}{\omega\left(\omega+\omega_{\mathrm{c}}\right)} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Since the phase velocity of electromagnetic waves in the medium, $c(\mu \varepsilon)^{-\frac{1}{2}} \approx c \varepsilon^{-\frac{1}{2}}$, may exceed the velocity of light speed $c$ in vacuum, the refractive index $n=\frac{c}{v}$ may be less than one. Physically, as

$$
n \approx \sqrt{\varepsilon}=\sqrt{1+4 \pi \chi_{\mathrm{e}}},
$$

where $\chi_{e}$ is the polarizability of the medium, $n<1$ means that $\chi_{e}<0$. As the electric dipole moment per electron is $\mathbf{p}=\chi_{\mathrm{e}} \mathbf{E}$, this means that the polarization vector $\mathbf{P}$ of the medium caused by the external waves is antiparallel to $\mathbf{E}$. With $\omega_{0}=0$, the group velocity $v_{\mathrm{g}}=c n$ (Problem 5051). Thus $v_{\mathrm{g}}=0$ when $n=0$. This means that a signal consisting of such waves will be turned back at that point. Consider the case $n_{\mathrm{L}}^{2}=0$. We have

$$
\omega^{2}+\omega_{c} \omega-\omega_{p}^{2}=0,
$$

or

$$
\omega=\omega_{L c}=\frac{-\omega_{c}+\sqrt{\omega_{c}^{2}+4 \omega_{p}^{2}}}{2} .
$$

Similarly we have for $n_{R}^{2}=0$,

$$
\omega=\omega_{\mathrm{Rc}}=\frac{\omega_{\mathrm{c}}+\sqrt{\omega_{\mathrm{c}}^{2}+4 \omega_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}}}{2} .
$$

Thus $\omega_{\mathrm{Rc}}>\omega_{\mathrm{Lc}}$. If $\omega>\omega_{\mathrm{Rc}}$, then both $n_{\mathrm{R}}$ and $n_{\mathrm{L}}$ are real, and propagation is possible for both polarizations. A plane electromagnetic wave in the medium will split into two circularly polarized waves with different refraction properties. If $\omega_{\mathrm{Rc}}>\omega>\omega_{\mathrm{Lc}}, n_{\mathrm{R}}$ is imaginary and propagation is possible for only the left circularly polarized wave. A plane electromagnetic wave will become left circularly polarized in the medium. If $\omega<\omega_{\mathrm{Lc}}$, then propagation is not possible for both circular polarizations. Note that for $n$ imaginary, say $n=i \eta, e^{i k r}=e^{-\eta r}$ and the amplitude attenuates exponentially.

If $\omega=\omega_{c}, n_{R}=i \infty, n_{L}=\left(1-\frac{\omega_{p}^{2}}{2 \omega_{c}^{2}}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}$. As $\omega_{\mathrm{p}} \gg \omega_{\mathrm{c}}$ generally, $n_{\mathrm{L}}$ is also a large imaginary number. No propagation is possible. Both $n_{R}, n_{L}=i \infty$ if $\omega=0$. In such a case, there is no wave but only an electrostatic field which separates the positive and negative charges at the boundary of the plasma. Then the plasma surface acts as a shield to external electrostatic fields.

\section{4}

A radio source in space emits a pulse of "noise" containing a wide band of frequencies. Because of dispersion in the interstellar medium the pulse arrives at the earth as a whistle whose frequency changes with time. If this rate of change (frequency versus time) is measured and the distance $D$ to the source is known, show that it is possible to deduce the average electron density in the interstellar medium (assumed fully ionized). (Hint: Look at the response of a free electron to a high frequency electric field to deduce the relation between frequency and the wave number $2 \pi / \lambda)$.

$(C U S P E A)$

\section{Solution:}

Considering the interstellar medium as a tenuous plasma, we have from Problem 5044

$$
n=\left(1-\omega_{\mathrm{p}}^{2} / \omega^{2}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}
$$

where $\omega$ is the frequency of the transversing radio wave, $\omega_{p}=\sqrt{\frac{N e^{2}}{m \varepsilon_{0}}}$ is the plasma frequency of the medium, $N$ being the average number density of the electrons in the medium. With the wave number $k=\frac{\omega}{c} n$, the group velocity $v_{\mathrm{g}}$ of the electromagnetic wave is given by

$$
v_{\mathrm{g}}^{-1}=\frac{d k}{d \omega}=\frac{n}{c}+\frac{\omega}{c} \frac{d n}{d \omega} .
$$

Equation (1) gives $\frac{d n}{d \omega}=\frac{\omega_{p}^{2}}{\omega^{3}} \cdot \frac{1}{n}$, so that

$$
v_{\mathrm{g}}=n c\left(n^{2}+\frac{\omega_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}}{\omega^{2}}\right)^{-1}=n c .
$$

Since a pulse propagates with the group velocity, the propagating time from the source to the earth is approximately

$$
t=\frac{D}{v_{\mathrm{g}}}=\frac{D}{n c}=\frac{D}{c}\left(1-\frac{\omega_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}}{\omega^{2}}\right)^{-\frac{1}{2}} .
$$

Thus

$$
d t=\frac{D}{c} \cdot\left(-\frac{1}{2}\right)\left(1-\frac{\omega_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}}{\omega^{2}}\right)^{-\frac{3}{2}}\left(2 \frac{\omega_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}}{\omega^{3}}\right) d \omega
$$

or

$$
\frac{d \omega}{d t}=-\frac{c}{D} \frac{\omega^{3}}{\omega_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}}\left(1-\frac{\omega_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}}{\omega^{2}}\right)^{\frac{3}{2}}
$$

Thus if $D$ and $\frac{d \omega}{d t}$ are known, we can calculate $\omega_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}=\frac{N e^{2}}{m \varepsilon_{0}}$ and hence the average electron density $N$. 

\section{5}

A pulsar emits a pulse of broadband electromagnetic radiation which is 1 millisecond in duration. This pulse then propagates 1000 light years $\left(10^{21} \mathrm{~cm}\right)$ through interstellar space to reach radio astronomers on earth.

(a) What must be the minimum bandwidth of a radio telescope receiver in order that the observed pulse shape be not distorted greatly?

(b) Now consider that the interstellar medium contains a low density plasma (plasma frequency $\omega_{p}=5000$ radians/sec). Estimate the difference in measured pulse arrival times for radio telescopes operating at $400 \mathrm{MHz}$ and $1000 \mathrm{MHz}$. Recall that the dispersion relation for a plasma is $\omega^{2}=$ $k^{2} c^{2}+\omega_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}$

Solution:

(a) The uncertainty principle $\Delta \nu \Delta t \approx 1$ gives the minimum bandwidth of the radio telescope receiver as

$$
\Delta \nu \sim \frac{1}{\Delta t}=10^{3} \mathrm{~Hz} .
$$
medium is

(b) The group velocity of electromagnetic waves in the interstellar

$$
v_{\mathrm{g}}=\frac{\partial \omega}{\partial k}=c \sqrt{1-\omega_{\mathrm{p}}^{2} / \omega^{2}} \text {. }
$$

For operating frequencies $\omega_{1}=4 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}, \omega_{2}=10^{9} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}$ we have

$$
\frac{\omega_{p}}{\omega_{1}}=1.25 \times 10^{-5}, \frac{\omega_{p}}{\omega_{2}}=10^{-6} \text {. }
$$

With an interstellar distance $L=10^{19} \mathrm{~m}$, the difference in the measured pulse arrival times is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Delta t=\frac{L}{v_{\mathrm{g} 1}}-\frac{L}{v_{\mathrm{g} 2}} &=\frac{L}{c}\left[\left(1-\frac{\omega_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}}{\omega_{1}^{2}}\right)^{-\frac{1}{2}}-\left(1-\frac{\omega_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}}{\omega_{2}^{2}}\right)^{-\frac{1}{2}}\right] \\
& \approx \frac{L}{2 c}\left[\left(\frac{\omega_{\mathrm{p}}}{\omega_{1}}\right)^{2}-\left(\frac{\omega_{\mathrm{p}}}{\omega_{2}}\right)^{2}\right]=0.052 \mathrm{~s} .
\end{aligned}
$$

\section{6}

A pulsar emits short regularly spaced burst of radio waves which have been observed, e.g., at the frequencies $\omega_{1}=2 \pi f_{1}=2563 \mathrm{MHz}$ and $\omega_{2}=$ $2 \pi f_{2}=3833 \mathrm{MHz}$. It is noted that the arrival times of these bursts are delayed at the lower frequencies: the pulse at $f_{1}$ arrives $0.367$ sec after the pulse at $\boldsymbol{f}_{2}$. Attributing this delay to dispersion in the interstellar medium which is assumed to consist of ionized hydrogen with $10^{5}$ electrons per $\mathrm{m}^{3}$, give an estimate for the distance of this pulsar from earth.

(a) Show that the electron plasma frequency for a tenuous neutral gas consisting of heavy ions and free electrons is given in Gaussian units by

$$
\omega_{\mathrm{p}}=\left(\frac{4 \pi N e^{2}}{m_{\mathrm{e}}}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}},
$$

where $N$ is the electron density.

(b) Using that result and remembering that the index of refraction of a tenuous plasma is given by $n=\sqrt{\varepsilon}=\left(1-\frac{\omega_{p}^{2}}{\omega^{2}}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}$, calculate the distance of the pulsar.

(Chicago)

\section{Solution:}

(a) In a neutral plasma, when the distribution of the electrons is perturbed and undulates non-uniformly, an electric field will be produced which causes the electrons to move in a way to tend to return the plasma to the neutral state. The characteristic (angular) frequency of the undulation can be estimated as follows. Consider an electron of the plasma in an electric field $\mathbf{E}$, the equation of motion is

$$
m_{\mathrm{e}} \frac{d \mathbf{v}}{d t}=-e \mathbf{E}
$$

\section{The motion of electrons produces a current of density}

$$
\mathbf{j}=-N e \mathbf{v} .
$$

Combining the above we have

$$
\frac{\partial \mathbf{j}}{\partial t}=\frac{N e^{2}}{m_{\mathrm{e}}} \mathbf{E}
$$

or, taking divergence of the two sides,

$$
\frac{\partial}{\partial t}(\nabla \cdot \mathbf{j})=\frac{N e^{2}}{m} \nabla \cdot \mathbf{E} .
$$

Using the continuity equation $\nabla \cdot \mathbf{j}=-\frac{\partial \rho}{\partial t}$ and Maxwell's equation $\nabla \cdot \mathbf{E}=$ $4 \pi \rho$, we obtain

$$
\frac{\partial^{2} \rho}{\partial t^{2}}+\frac{4 \pi N e^{2}}{m_{e}} \rho=0,
$$

or

$$
\frac{\partial^{2} \rho}{\partial t^{2}}+\omega_{\mathrm{p}}^{2} \rho=0
$$

with

$$
\omega_{\mathrm{p}}=\sqrt{\frac{4 \pi N e^{2}}{m_{\mathrm{e}}}} .
$$

This equation shows that the charge density at a point oscillates simple harmonically with characteristic (angular) frequency $\omega_{p}$.

(b) Using the results of Problem 5055 we find the distance from the pulsar to the earth:

$$
L=c \Delta t\left[\left(1-\frac{\omega_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}}{\omega_{1}^{2}}\right)^{-\frac{1}{2}}-\left(1-\frac{\omega_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}}{\omega_{2}^{2}}\right)^{-\frac{1}{2}}\right]^{-1}
$$

The electron plasma frequency

$$
\omega_{p}=\sqrt{\frac{4 \pi N e^{2}}{m_{e}}}=\sqrt{4 \pi N r_{0} c^{2}}=1.79 \times 10^{4} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}
$$

$r_{0}=2.82 \times 10^{-13} \mathrm{~cm}$ being the classical radius of electron.

The observed (angular) frequencies are $\omega_{1}=2.563 \times 10^{9} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}, \omega_{2}=$ $3.833 \times 10^{9} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}$. As $\omega_{1}, \omega_{2} \gg \omega_{\mathrm{p}}$ we have approximately

$$
L \approx \frac{2 c \Delta t}{\omega_{p}^{2}\left(\frac{1}{\omega_{1}^{2}}-\frac{1}{\omega_{2}^{2}}\right)} .
$$

With $\Delta t=0.367 \mathrm{~s}$

$$
L=8.16 \times 10^{20} \mathrm{~cm}=8.5 \times 10^{2} \text { light years } .
$$

field of 2001, 2002, 2003, 2004, 2006, 2007, 2018, 2024

with hole 2030

Current element

in magnetic field 2068

magnetic moment of 2010

dc circuit $3001,3002,3003,3005,3019$

De Morgan relation 3058

Depth of penetration 4028

Derandomizer 3071

\section{Major American Universities Ph.D. Qualifying Questions and Solutions}

\section{PROBLEMS AND SOLUTIONS ON ELECTROMAGNETISM}

The material for these volumes has been selected from the past twenty years' examination questions for graduate students at the University of California at Berkeley, Columbia University, the University of Chicago, the MIT, the State University of New York at Buffalo, Princeton University and the University of Wisconsin.

This volume comprises 440 problems and is divided into five parts:

(I) Electrostatics;

(II) Magnetostatic Field and Quasi-Stationary Electromagnetic Field;

(III) Circuit Analysis;

(IV) Electromagnetic Waves;

(V) Relativistic Particle-Field Interactions.
